diagnostics.title: No enclosing loop from which to break.

blocks.html: The keyword break must be used inside the body of a loop statement such as while, for, repeat, or with.
blocks.text: The keyword break must be used inside the body of a loop statement such as while, for, repeat, or with.

blocks.html: Usage outside of a loop statement is not possible and results in a Compile Error.
blocks.text: Usage outside of a loop statement is not possible and results in a Compile Error.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _items = get_items();
var i = 0;
repeat (array_length(_items))
{
    var _item = _items[i++];
    if (_item == undefined)
        break; // Good!
    // ... Some logic here ...
}
break; // GM1000 - No loop to break from.

Correcting this error requires identifying where the break statement was intended to go and moving it to the correct location. In the above example there was no loop to break from and thus the fix is to simply remove the last break statement.
blocks.text: Correcting this error requires identifying where the break statement was intended to go and moving it to the correct location. In the above example there was no loop to break from and thus the fix is to simply remove the last break statement.

diagnostics.title: No enclosing loop from which to continue.

blocks.html: The keyword continue must be used inside the body of a loop statement such as while, for, repeat, or with.
blocks.text: The keyword continue must be used inside the body of a loop statement such as while, for, repeat, or with.

blocks.html: Usage outside of a loop statement is not possible and results in a Compile Error.
blocks.text: Usage outside of a loop statement is not possible and results in a Compile Error.

blocks.html:
var _items = get_items();
var i = 0;
repeat (array_length(_items))
{
    var _item = _items[i++];
    if (_item == undefined)
        continue; // Good!
    // ... Some logic here ...
}
continue; // GM1001 - No loop to continue from.

Correcting this error requires identifying where the continue statement was intended to go and moving it to the correct location. In the above example there was no loop to continue from and thus the fix is to simply remove the last continue statement.
blocks.text: Correcting this error requires identifying where the continue statement was intended to go and moving it to the correct location. In the above example there was no loop to continue from and thus the fix is to simply remove the last continue statement.

diagnostics.title: globalvar does not support inline initializers.

blocks.html: When using globalvar's you must split the declaration and initialization of its value. This is in contrast to local variables which can be declared and initialized in the same statement (e.g. var _width = 100;).
blocks.text: When using globalvar's you must split the declaration and initialization of its value. This is in contrast to local variables which can be declared and initialized in the same statement (e.g. var _width = 100;).

blocks.html: Attempting to initialize a globalvar inline in this manner is invalid syntax and results in a Compile Error.
blocks.text: Attempting to initialize a globalvar inline in this manner is invalid syntax and results in a Compile Error.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: globalvar gameManager = new GameManager(); // GM1002 - globalvar does not support inline initializers.
blocks.text: globalvar gameManager = new GameManager(); // GM1002 - globalvar does not support inline initializers.

blocks.html: Correcting this error requires splitting the declaration and initialization statements. The above example can be fixed by rewriting it as so:
blocks.text: Correcting this error requires splitting the declaration and initialization statements. The above example can be fixed by rewriting it as so:

blocks.html:
globalvar gameManager;
gameManager = new GameManager();
blocks.text:
globalvar gameManager;

    gameManager = new GameManager();

diagnostics.title: Enum assignment must be integer assignment.

blocks.html: When declaring the members of an enum you can assign specific integer values to the members. You cannot assign any other type of value to these members however. Attempting to do so will result in a Compile Error.
blocks.text: When declaring the members of an enum you can assign specific integer values to the members. You cannot assign any other type of value to these members however. Attempting to do so will result in a Compile Error.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT
{
    UNKNOWN = -1, // Good!
    BANANA,
    ORANGE,
    APPLE = "apple" // GM1003 - Enum assignment must be integer assignment.
}
blocks.text:
enum FRUIT

    {

        UNKNOWN = -1, // Good!

        BANANA,

        ORANGE,

        APPLE = "apple" // GM1003 - Enum assignment must be integer assignment.

    }

blocks.html: Correcting this error requires changing the assigned value to an integer in some way. If your code requires a value type other than Real for some reason then you may want to investigate using macros instead.
blocks.text: Correcting this error requires changing the assigned value to an integer in some way. If your code requires a value type other than Real for some reason then you may want to investigate using macros instead.

blocks.html:
// Approach 1
enum FRUIT
{
    UNKNOWN = -1, // Good!
    BANANA,
    ORANGE,
    APPLE = 10 // Good!
}

// Approach 2
#macro FRUIT_UNKNOWN     -1
#macro FRUIT_BANANA     0
#macro FRUIT_ORANGE     1
#macro FRUIT_APPLE     "apple"

diagnostics.title: The enum value 'ENUM MEMBER NAME' has already been previously defined in the enum 'ENUM NAME'.

blocks.html: Enum members must be uniquely named, duplicate names will result in a Compile Error.
blocks.text: Enum members must be uniquely named, duplicate names will result in a Compile Error.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT
{
    APPLE, // Good!
    APPLE, // GM1004 The enum value 'APPLE' has already been previously defined in the enum 'FRUIT'
}
Typically, this error is the result of a typo of oversight. Removing the duplicate declaration will fix the issue.
blocks.text: Typically, this error is the result of a typo of oversight. Removing the duplicate declaration will fix the issue.

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT
{
    APPLE, // Good!
}

diagnostics.title: Argument must be provided.

blocks.html: A function's parameter is required, yet an argument was not passed. While some parameters are optional (denoted with [square brackets]), most are required. When no argument is passed to these parameters, a compile error occurs.
blocks.text: A function's parameter is required, yet an argument was not passed. While some parameters are optional (denoted with [square brackets]), most are required. When no argument is passed to these parameters, a compile error occurs.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: draw_set_color(); // GM1005 - Argument must be provided.
blocks.text: draw_set_color(); // GM1005 - Argument must be provided.

blocks.html: Typically, this error is the result of an oversight. Providing the missing argument will fix the issue.
blocks.text: Typically, this error is the result of an oversight. Providing the missing argument will fix the issue.

blocks.html: draw_set_color(c_black); // Good!
blocks.text: draw_set_color(c_black); // Good!

diagnostics.title: The enum 'ENUM NAME' has already been previously declared.

blocks.html: Enums must be uniquely named, duplicate names will result in a compile error.
blocks.text: Enums must be uniquely named, duplicate names will result in a compile error.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT {
    APPLE,
    ORANGE,
    BLUEBERRY
}
enum FRUIT // GM1006 - The enum 'FRUIT' has already been previously declared.
{
    APPLE,
    ORANGE,
    CHERRY
}

Typically, this error is the result of an oversight. Removing the duplicate declaration, merging members of applicable will fix the issue. If the enums are intended to be different but names conflict, consider a different name for the new enum.
blocks.text: Typically, this error is the result of an oversight. Removing the duplicate declaration, merging members of applicable will fix the issue. If the enums are intended to be different but names conflict, consider a different name for the new enum.

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT
{
    APPLE,
    ORANGE,
    BLUEBERRY,
    CHERRY
}
blocks.text:
enum FRUIT

    {

        APPLE,

        ORANGE,

        BLUEBERRY,

        CHERRY

    }

diagnostics.title: Left-hand side of an assignment must be a variable.

blocks.html: The assignment operator = requires that the left-hand side of the statement be a variable. Constants, and other non-variables cannot be logically assigned to. E.g. 1 = 2 is not a mathematically valid statement.
blocks.text: The assignment operator = requires that the left-hand side of the statement be a variable. Constants, and other non-variables cannot be logically assigned to. E.g. 1 = 2 is not a mathematically valid statement.

blocks.html: A variable assignment stores the value on the right-hand side of the = sign somewhere in the computer's memory and makes it accessible in code through the name that you write on the left. If the variable already exists, the assignment will replace its contents with the new value on the right-hand side. Instances, structs, functions, constants and asset IDs are all non-variables and cannot be assigned to. You can, however, assign a value to one of the variables of an instance, struct or function.
blocks.text: A variable assignment stores the value on the right-hand side of the = sign somewhere in the computer's memory and makes it accessible in code through the name that you write on the left. If the variable already exists, the assignment will replace its contents with the new value on the right-hand side. Instances, structs, functions, constants and asset IDs are all non-variables and cannot be assigned to. You can, however, assign a value to one of the variables of an instance, struct or function.

blocks.html: For more info on variable assignment see Variables And Variable Scope.
blocks.text: For more info on variable assignment see Variables And Variable Scope.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _foo = 1234;
_foo = 4321; // Good!

function get_random_item()
{
    return
    {
        name: "Sword"
    };
}

get_random_item() = "Shield"; // GM1007 - Left-hand side of an assignment must be a variable

Typically, this error is the result of a typo or oversight. Sometimes it's the result of a misunderstanding of how data flows through a program. If this is the case, take a step back and think about what you're trying to communicate to the CPU.
blocks.text: Typically, this error is the result of a typo or oversight. Sometimes it's the result of a misunderstanding of how data flows through a program. If this is the case, take a step back and think about what you're trying to communicate to the CPU.

blocks.html:
var _foo = 1234;
_foo = 4321; // Good!

function get_random_item()
{
    return
    {
        name: "Sword"
    };
}

get_random_item() = { name: "Shield" }; // Bad! Return values are not variables
get_random_item().name = "Shield"; // Good!
vk_space = vk_tab; // Bad! Constants are not variables and cannot change

diagnostics.title: The variable 'BUILT-IN VARIABLE' is readonly and cannot be assigned to.

blocks.html: Attempting to assign a value to a read-only built-in variable is not allowed. These variables can be read and assigned to other variables or used in expressions, but cannot have their value directly modified.
blocks.text: Attempting to assign a value to a read-only built-in variable is not allowed. These variables can be read and assigned to other variables or used in expressions, but cannot have their value directly modified.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
working_directory = @"PlayerData"; // Bad! working_directory is readonly
var _file = file_find_first(working_directory + @"\Screenshots\*.png", fa_archive);
// ...

Since read-only variables cannot be directly assigned to the fix will depend on what your intention with setting the variable is. In the above example, we intend to find all the files in a directory "PlayerData\Screenshots\" relative to our working_directory. For this we can just use a local variable instead.
blocks.text: Since read-only variables cannot be directly assigned to the fix will depend on what your intention with setting the variable is. In the above example, we intend to find all the files in a directory "PlayerData\Screenshots\" relative to our working_directory. For this we can just use a local variable instead.

blocks.html:
var _playerdata_directory = working_directory + @"PlayerData";
var _file = file_find_first(_playerdata_directory + @"\Screenshots\*.png", fa_archive);
// ...

diagnostics.title: Operation OPERATOR between types 'TYPE' and 'TYPE' may result in unexpected behavior or an error during runtime.

blocks.html: This indicates that the specified operation, while valid, may not have the result or behaviour that is expected. You may see this when adding reals to constant or asset types; which is an abuse of these types. Constant values are intended to be used in very specific ways, and asset IDs are not safely modifiable.
blocks.text: This indicates that the specified operation, while valid, may not have the result or behaviour that is expected. You may see this when adding reals to constant or asset types; which is an abuse of these types. Constant values are intended to be used in very specific ways, and asset IDs are not safely modifiable.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
// Find all *.doc files that are readonly archives
var _attribs = fa_readonly + fa_archive; // Warn!
var _filename = file_find_first("/User Content/*.doc", _attribs);

// Go to the next room
room_goto(room + 1); // Warn!

In the above example we have 2 problems: Adding constants that are meant to be flags, and adding 1 to the current room ID to find the next room. The tricky bit is that this code might just work! But it's brittle and unrelated changes to the Runner or even your Game Project might break this code! Why?
blocks.text: In the above example we have 2 problems: Adding constants that are meant to be flags, and adding 1 to the current room ID to find the next room. The tricky bit is that this code might just work! But it's brittle and unrelated changes to the Runner or even your Game Project might break this code! Why?

blocks.html: Bitfield Constants
blocks.text: Bitfield Constants

blocks.html: When it comes to constants used as bit field flags you should use the Bitwise OR operation | instead of the Arithmetic Add operation +. If we were to consider fa_readonly as 0b0001 and fa_archive as 0b0010 and we added (0b0001 + 0b0010 = 0b0011) these two together we would get the same result as if we or'd the values (0b0001 | 0b0010 = 0b0011). However, if for some reason the value of fa_readonly changed to be 0b0011 with two set bits instead of one (perhaps it's a mask field, or represents two other values together) then we will suddenly end up with an incorrect value and our code will stop working. (0b0011 + 0b0001 = 0b0100, and 0b0011 | 0b0001 = 0b0011).
blocks.text: When it comes to constants used as bit field flags you should use the Bitwise OR operation | instead of the Arithmetic Add operation +. If we were to consider fa_readonly as 0b0001 and fa_archive as 0b0010 and we added (0b0001 + 0b0010 = 0b0011) these two together we would get the same result as if we or'd the values (0b0001 | 0b0010 = 0b0011). However, if for some reason the value of fa_readonly changed to be 0b0011 with two set bits instead of one (perhaps it's a mask field, or represents two other values together) then we will suddenly end up with an incorrect value and our code will stop working. (0b0011 + 0b0001 = 0b0100, and 0b0011 | 0b0001 = 0b0011).

blocks.html: Mutating Asset IDs
blocks.text: Mutating Asset IDs

blocks.html: Assets such as Rooms, Sprites and Objects are assigned an ordinal index number when your game is compiled. Which means that each asset is given a unique number that increments by 1 from 0. This may lead you to believe that if you wanted to get the next or previous room, for example, you can simply add or subtract 1 from the current room. However, the order that the rooms are in is different from the asset ID, perhaps you created the rooms out of order and then rearranged them, perhaps the method by which the compiler determines the asset IDs changes. In either of these instances your code would break. Instead you should use functions provided by the Runner for these specific tasks.
blocks.text: Assets such as Rooms, Sprites and Objects are assigned an ordinal index number when your game is compiled. Which means that each asset is given a unique number that increments by 1 from 0. This may lead you to believe that if you wanted to get the next or previous room, for example, you can simply add or subtract 1 from the current room. However, the order that the rooms are in is different from the asset ID, perhaps you created the rooms out of order and then rearranged them, perhaps the method by which the compiler determines the asset IDs changes. In either of these instances your code would break. Instead you should use functions provided by the Runner for these specific tasks.

blocks.html:
// Find all *.doc files that are readonly archives
var _attribs = fa_readonly | fa_archive; // Good!
var _filename = file_find_first("/User Content/*.doc", _attribs);

// Go to the next room
room_goto_next(); // Good!

diagnostics.title: Cannot perform OPERATOR operation between types 'TYPE' and 'TYPE'.

blocks.html: This indicates that the specified operation is invalid in such a way that no result can be produced and instead result in either a runtime or compile time error. You may see this error between some type and undefined or unset. If Feather is unable to determine the type of a variable (or the variable is genuinely unset) then this error will appear.
blocks.text: This indicates that the specified operation is invalid in such a way that no result can be produced and instead result in either a runtime or compile time error. You may see this error between some type and undefined or unset. If Feather is unable to determine the type of a variable (or the variable is genuinely unset) then this error will appear.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _item1 = { price: 10 };
var _item2 = { price: 20 };
var _diff = _item2 - _item1; // Error!
var _a, _b = 1234;
var _c = _a + _b; // Error!

This will require rewriting your code such that the intention is conveyed in valid operations. In the above example we intended to get the difference in price between 2 items. We can instead subtract the price variables, which are of type Real, instead of the structs themselves.
blocks.text: This will require rewriting your code such that the intention is conveyed in valid operations. In the above example we intended to get the difference in price between 2 items. We can instead subtract the price variables, which are of type Real, instead of the structs themselves.

blocks.html:
var _item1 = { price: 10 };
var _item2 = { price: 20 };
var _diff = _item2.price - _item1.price; // Good!
var _a = 4321, _b = 1234;
var _c = _a + _b; // Good!

diagnostics.title: Implicit cast of type 'TYPE' to 'Bool' may result in unexpected behavior or an error during runtime.

blocks.html: A common shorthand for if statement conditionals is to exclude the == false or == true from a boolean logic comparison. In GML doing so implicitly casts the conditional to a Boolean and compares it to true. Some types cannot be converted to Boolean and will result in a runtime error. The type Unset is special and indicates that you've declared a variable but never assigned a value to it, no operation is valid on Unset.
blocks.text: A common shorthand for if statement conditionals is to exclude the == false or == true from a boolean logic comparison. In GML doing so implicitly casts the conditional to a Boolean and compares it to true. Some types cannot be converted to Boolean and will result in a runtime error. The type Unset is special and indicates that you've declared a variable but never assigned a value to it, no operation is valid on Unset.

blocks.html: See: if / else and Conditional Operators
blocks.text: See: if / else and Conditional Operators

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _a = true;
var _b = 1234;
var _c = [];
var _d;
if (_a) { } // Good!
if (_b) { } // Good!
if (_c) { } // Error!
if (_d) { } // Error!
The solution is typically to be explicit about your comparisons.
blocks.text: The solution is typically to be explicit about your comparisons.

blocks.html:
• String, Array, Function, Struct, Id, Asset, Constant – != undefined
  • Bool – == true, or implicit cast still valid
  • Real – > 0, or implicit cast still valid (though discouraged)
  • Unset – Assign a value to it!
blocks.text:
String, Array, Function, Struct, Id, Asset, Constant – != undefined
    Bool – == true, or implicit cast still valid
    Real – > 0, or implicit cast still valid (though discouraged)
    Unset – Assign a value to it!

blocks.html:
var _a = true;
var _b = 1234;
var _c = [];
var _d;
if (_a == true) { } // Good!
if (_a) { } // Good!
if (_b > 0) { } // Good!
if (_b) { } // Good!
if (_c != undefined) { } // Good!
_d = true; // Assign a value to change from Unset
if (_d) { } // Good!

diagnostics.title: Malformed variable addressing expression.

blocks.html: The dot operator is used to access a variable that exists in another scope. These dot operators can be chained together or exist alone, in either occurrence this is known in GML as a "variable addressing expression", as it is an expression that gives a variable's address. Usually the left-hand side of this expression is a variable or constant containing an Object Asset, Instance ID, or Struct. Other types cannot be on the left-hand side because they do not contain variables.
blocks.text: The dot operator is used to access a variable that exists in another scope. These dot operators can be chained together or exist alone, in either occurrence this is known in GML as a "variable addressing expression", as it is an expression that gives a variable's address. Usually the left-hand side of this expression is a variable or constant containing an Object Asset, Instance ID, or Struct. Other types cannot be on the left-hand side because they do not contain variables.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _a = { name: "GameMaker" };
var _b = _a.name; // Good!
var _c = obj_manager.name; // Good!
var _d = "name".length; // Error!
blocks.text:
var _a = { name: "GameMaker" };

    var _b = _a.name; // Good!

    var _c = obj_manager.name; // Good!

    var _d = "name".length; // Error!

blocks.html: Correcting this error depends on what is on the left-hand side of the expression. You likely intended to reference a variable from an Object Asset, Instance, or Struct but either typo'd the name or your variable contains a different type than was expected.
blocks.text: Correcting this error depends on what is on the left-hand side of the expression. You likely intended to reference a variable from an Object Asset, Instance, or Struct but either typo'd the name or your variable contains a different type than was expected.

blocks.html: var _d = string_length("name"); // Good!
blocks.text: var _d = string_length("name"); // Good!

diagnostics.title: Reference to variable 'IDENTIFIER' which has not been previously declared in 'IDENTIFIER'.

blocks.html: This error indicates that the specified variable cannot be found in the referenced scope.
blocks.text: This error indicates that the specified variable cannot be found in the referenced scope.

blocks.html: This could indicate that:
blocks.text: This could indicate that:

blocks.html:
// Create event
var atk = 1;
if (atk < 50) {    // Error! 'atk' is a local variable in Create
    with (other) {
        hp -= atk; // Error! 'atk' is in the original scope!
    }
    
    attack *= 2;   // Error! Typo'd 'atk' as 'attack'
}

// Script - Item
function Item(_name, _value) constructor {
    name = _name;
    value = _value;
}

// Create - objInventory
hp = 100;
items = [];
var _sword = new Item("Sword", 10);
array_push(items, _sword);
var _shield = new Item("Shield", 10);
_shield.defense = 10;
array_push(items, _shield);

// Collision - par_mob
var _dmg = other.dmg;
var _len = array_length(items);
for (var i = 0; i < _len; ++i) {
    var _item = items[i];
    _dmg -= _item.defense; // Error! 'defense' is conditionally defined
}

hp -= max(0, _dmg);
Correcting this issue depends on which of the aforementioned conditions applies to your situation.
blocks.text: Correcting this issue depends on which of the aforementioned conditions applies to your situation.

blocks.html:
// Create event
atk = 1; // Fix! Make this an instance variable by removing 'var'
// Collision - par_mob
if (atk < 50) { // Good!
    with (other) {
        hp -= other.atk; // Fix! Reference 'other.atk'
    }
    
    atk *= 2; // Fix! Rename to 'atk'
}

// Script - Item
function Item(_name, _value) constructor {
    name = _name;
    value = _value;
    defense = 0; // Possible Fix! Declare a default value
}

// Create - objInventory
hp = 100;
items = [];
var _sword = new Item("Sword", 10);
array_push(items, _sword);
var _shield = new Item("Shield", 10);
_shield.defense = 10;
array_push(items, _shield);

// Collision - par_mob
var _dmg = other.dmg;
var _len = array_length(items);
for (var i = 0; i < _len; ++i) {
    var _item = items[i];
    _dmg -= _item.defense; // Fix! 'defense' has default value
    // Or Possible Fix! Check variable exists (not as recommended)
    if (struct_exists(_item, "defense")) {
        _dmg -= _item.defense; // Feather knows this variable exists now
    }
}

hp -= max(0, _dmg);

diagnostics.title: The enum 'ENUM' does not contain the value 'IDENTIFIER'.

blocks.html: This error is raised when an Enum Member is referenced which does not exist.
blocks.text: This error is raised when an Enum Member is referenced which does not exist.

blocks.html: This could indicate that:
blocks.text: This could indicate that:

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT {
    NONE,
    ORANGE,
    APPLE,
    CANTALOUPE,
    SIZEOF
}
var _best_fruit = FRUIT.KIWI; // Error! KIWI is not defined
var _underrated_fruit = FRUIT.CANALOPE; // Error! CANTALOUPE is typo'd
blocks.text:
enum FRUIT {

        NONE,

        ORANGE,

        APPLE,

        CANTALOUPE,

        SIZEOF

    }

    var _best_fruit = FRUIT.KIWI; // Error! KIWI is not defined

    var _underrated_fruit = FRUIT.CANALOPE; // Error! CANTALOUPE is typo'd

blocks.html: Correcting this issue depends on which of the aforementioned conditions applies to your situation.
blocks.text: Correcting this issue depends on which of the aforementioned conditions applies to your situation.

blocks.html:
enum FRUIT {
    NONE,
    ORANGE,
    APPLE,
    CANTALOUPE,
    KIWI, // Fix! Define KIWI
    SIZEOF
}
var _best_fruit = FRUIT.KIWI; // Good!
var _underrated_fruit = FRUIT.CANTALOUPE; // Fix! No longer typo'd
blocks.text:
enum FRUIT {

        NONE,

        ORANGE,

        APPLE,

        CANTALOUPE,

        KIWI, // Fix! Define KIWI

        SIZEOF

    }

    var _best_fruit = FRUIT.KIWI; // Good!

    var _underrated_fruit = FRUIT.CANTALOUPE; // Fix! No longer typo'd

diagnostics.title: Cannot divide or modulo expression by 0.

blocks.html: This error is raised when you directly divide or modulo by 0.
blocks.text: This error is raised when you directly divide or modulo by 0.

blocks.html: Note: GM1015 is NOT raised if 0 is stored in a variable and then you divide by that variable; Feather does not track the individual values of variables, only the types of variables.
blocks.text: Note: GM1015 is NOT raised if 0 is stored in a variable and then you divide by that variable; Feather does not track the individual values of variables, only the types of variables.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _hp = 100;
_hp /= 0; // Error! Cannot divide by 0
_hp %= 0; // Error! Cannot modulo by 0
The solution is to use any number other than 0.
blocks.text: The solution is to use any number other than 0.

blocks.html:
var _hp = 100;
_hp /= 100; // Good!
_hp %= 100; // Good!

diagnostics.title: A boolean literal was unexpected at this time.

blocks.html: This message indicates that a boolean value (true or false) has appeared outside of a conditional or expression. Typically you would only see these kinds of values used in if statements and friends.
blocks.text: This message indicates that a boolean value (true or false) has appeared outside of a conditional or expression. Typically you would only see these kinds of values used in if statements and friends.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: true; // Error! A lone true without a conditional
blocks.text: true; // Error! A lone true without a conditional

blocks.html: Use boolean values in a way that the compiler understands. For example:
blocks.text: Use boolean values in a way that the compiler understands. For example:

blocks.html:
var _a = true; // Good! Right-hand side is an expression
var _b = true ? 1 : 0; // Good! Right-hand side is an expression
if (true) {
    // Good! Appears inside a conditional
}

diagnostics.title: The function 'FUNCTION NAME' is deprecated and usage is discouraged.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you are using either a built-in function or user-defined function that is deprecated. Deprecation means that while the function, variable, or feature is still available for usage that it is planned to be removed in the future. Typically when something is deprecated a superior approach exists and is intended to be used instead. You should research what the alternative is and use that instead to avoid your code from breaking when you update GameMaker to newer versions.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you are using either a built-in function or user-defined function that is deprecated. Deprecation means that while the function, variable, or feature is still available for usage that it is planned to be removed in the future. Typically when something is deprecated a superior approach exists and is intended to be used instead. You should research what the alternative is and use that instead to avoid your code from breaking when you update GameMaker to newer versions.

blocks.html: Note that user-defined functions can also be marked as deprecated using the @deprecated tag.
blocks.text: Note that user-defined functions can also be marked as deprecated using the @deprecated tag.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
// @deprecated
function make_game() {
    // Deprecated in favour of writing more code to do that same thing!
}

username = get_string("Username:", ""); // Suggestion!
make_game(); // Suggestion!
Find the alternative functions or approach to use, and refactor your code to do that instead.
blocks.text: Find the alternative functions or approach to use, and refactor your code to do that instead.

blocks.html: username = get_string_async("Username:", ""); // Fix!
blocks.text: username = get_string_async("Username:", ""); // Fix!

diagnostics.title: The function 'FUNCTION NAME' takes no more than NUMBER arguments but NUMBER are provided.

blocks.html: This message is shown when more arguments are passed to a function than that function takes, including optional parameters (if they exist).
blocks.text: This message is shown when more arguments are passed to a function than that function takes, including optional parameters (if they exist).

blocks.html: There are essentially two reasons you might run into this problem:
blocks.text: There are essentially two reasons you might run into this problem:

blocks.html:
• You're nesting function calls and missed a closing parenthesis )
  • You have miscounted your arguments
blocks.text:
You're nesting function calls and missed a closing parenthesis )
    You have miscounted your arguments

blocks.html: The solution to fixing either of these is to refactor your code to reflect your actual intentions.
blocks.text: The solution to fixing either of these is to refactor your code to reflect your actual intentions.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2, 0.5, 0, 100)); // Error!
blocks.text: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2, 0.5, 0, 100)); // Error!

blocks.html: In the above example we have accidentally put the closing parenthesis for lerp in the wrong place.
blocks.text: In the above example we have accidentally put the closing parenthesis for lerp in the wrong place.

blocks.html: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2, 0.5), 0, 100); // Fix!
blocks.text: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2, 0.5), 0, 100); // Fix!

diagnostics.title: The function 'FUNCTION NAME' takes no less than NUMBER arguments but NUMBER are provided.

blocks.html: This message is shown when less arguments are passed to a function than that function takes.
blocks.text: This message is shown when less arguments are passed to a function than that function takes.

blocks.html: Possible causes can be:
blocks.text: Possible causes can be:

blocks.html:
• You're nesting function calls and missed a closing parenthesis )
  • You have miscounted your arguments
blocks.text:
You're nesting function calls and missed a closing parenthesis )
    You have miscounted your arguments

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2), 0.5, 0, 100); // Error!
blocks.text: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2), 0.5, 0, 100); // Error!

blocks.html: The closing parenthesis for lerp is in the wrong place.  Placing it after the 0.5 value instead fixes the error.
blocks.text: The closing parenthesis for lerp is in the wrong place. Placing it after the 0.5 value instead fixes the error.

blocks.html: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2, 0.5), 0, 100); // Fix!
blocks.text: var _dmg = clamp(lerp(dmg1, dmg2, 0.5), 0, 100); // Fix!

diagnostics.title: The function or script 'FUNCTION/SCRIPT NAME' does not exist.

blocks.html: This message is shown when a call to a non-existent script or function is made. This may be shown if you typo the function name, or have deleted the function.
blocks.text: This message is shown when a call to a non-existent script or function is made. This may be shown if you typo the function name, or have deleted the function.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function make_game(_genre) { /* ... */ }
make_gaem("RPG"); // GM1021
var _x = clam(x, 0, 100); // GM1021
Correct any typos, and ensure the functions you're trying to call exist.
blocks.text: Correct any typos, and ensure the functions you're trying to call exist.

blocks.html:
function make_game(_genre) { /* ... */ }
make_game("RPG"); // Fix!
var _x = clamp(x, 0, 100); // Fix!

diagnostics.title: An assignment was expected at this time.

blocks.html: This message is shown when a variable name is written as the left-hand side of an assignment and isn't followed by the assignment operator =.
blocks.text: This message is shown when a variable name is written as the left-hand side of an assignment and isn't followed by the assignment operator =.

blocks.html: Note that this does not apply to the var statement, as var a; suffices as a declaration.
blocks.text: Note that this does not apply to the var statement, as var a; suffices as a declaration.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
username                                // Error!
// OR
username;                               // Error!
An identifier cannot stand on its own in a statement. The issue can be fixed by using it in an assignment or by calling it as a function (in case it refers to a valid script function).
blocks.text: An identifier cannot stand on its own in a statement. The issue can be fixed by using it in an assignment or by calling it as a function (in case it refers to a valid script function).

blocks.html:
username = get_string("Username:", ""); // Valid Assignment!
username(); // Function Call is also possible
blocks.text:
username = get_string("Username:", ""); // Valid Assignment!

    username(); // Function Call is also possible

diagnostics.title: The constant 'BUILT-IN CONSTANT' is deprecated and usage is discouraged.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you're using a built-in constant that is deprecated.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you're using a built-in constant that is deprecated.

blocks.html: Deprecation means that while the constant is still available for usage, it is planned to be removed in the future. Typically when something is deprecated a superior approach exists and is intended to be used instead. You should research what the alternative is and use that instead to avoid your code from breaking when you update GameMaker to newer versions.
blocks.text: Deprecation means that while the constant is still available for usage, it is planned to be removed in the future. Typically when something is deprecated a superior approach exists and is intended to be used instead. You should research what the alternative is and use that instead to avoid your code from breaking when you update GameMaker to newer versions.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
if (os_type == os_win32) { // GM1023 - Constant 'os_win32' is deprecated
    global.config = 0;
}
else if (os_type == os_macosx) {
    global.config = 1;
    global.config = 2;
}

Depending on the constant, a replacement may be available. Check the manual to see if the page mentions this replacement. For the above example, the modern constant is os_windows (as to not imply a difference between detection of 32-bit and 64-bit Windows).
blocks.text: Depending on the constant, a replacement may be available. Check the manual to see if the page mentions this replacement. For the above example, the modern constant is os_windows (as to not imply a difference between detection of 32-bit and 64-bit Windows).

blocks.html:
if (os_type == os_windows) {
    global.config = 0;
}
else if (os_type == os_macosx) {
    global.config = 1;
    global.config = 2;
}

diagnostics.title: The built-in variable 'BUILT-IN VARIABLE' is deprecated and usage is discouraged.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you're using a built-in variable that is deprecated.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you're using a built-in variable that is deprecated.

blocks.html: Deprecation means that while the variable is still available for usage, it is planned to be removed in the future. Typically when something is deprecated a superior approach exists and is intended to be used instead. You should research what the alternative is and use that instead to avoid your code from breaking when you update GameMaker to newer versions.
blocks.text: Deprecation means that while the variable is still available for usage, it is planned to be removed in the future. Typically when something is deprecated a superior approach exists and is intended to be used instead. You should research what the alternative is and use that instead to avoid your code from breaking when you update GameMaker to newer versions.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
score = 0;

/// Step Event
var _ins = instance_position(mouse_x, mouse_y, obj_balloon);
if (_ins != noone)
{
    score++;
    instance_destroy(_ins);
}
Replace the variable with a custom variable or a macro, depending on what works best in the specific case.
blocks.text: Replace the variable with a custom variable or a macro, depending on what works best in the specific case.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
points = 0;

/// Step Event
var _ins = instance_position(mouse_x, mouse_y, obj_balloon);
if (_ins != noone)
{
    points++;
    instance_destroy(_ins);
}

diagnostics.title: A number literal was unexpected at this time.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you use a number literal outside of an expression where it cannot be used. It can occur when:
blocks.text: This message is shown when you use a number literal outside of an expression where it cannot be used. It can occur when:

blocks.html:
• A number literal is on its own in a statement
  • A number literal is used as the left-hand side of an assignment
blocks.text:
A number literal is on its own in a statement
    A number literal is used as the left-hand side of an assignment

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
#AEF033 // Error! Lone number literal
// OR:
#AEF033; // Error! Lone number literal
// OR:
0xFFDE31 = "value"; // Error! Left-hand side is not a variable
The number literal has to be used as a function parameter or as the right-hand side of an assignment.
blocks.text: The number literal has to be used as a function parameter or as the right-hand side of an assignment.

blocks.html: colour = #AEF033;
blocks.text: colour = #AEF033;

diagnostics.title: Left-hand side of postfix expression must be a variable.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you use a postfix increment (var++) or decrement operator (var--) on something that is not a variable. More precisely, it must be possible to assign to that which you'd normally write on the left-hand side of the equivalent equation:
blocks.text: This message is shown when you use a postfix increment (var++) or decrement operator (var--) on something that is not a variable. More precisely, it must be possible to assign to that which you'd normally write on the left-hand side of the equivalent equation:

blocks.html:
vari = vari + 1;    // Equivalent of vari++; - Variable can be written to and so can go on the left-hand side

pi = pi + 1;      // Equivalent of pi++; - Constant cannot be written to so cannot go on left-hand side
blocks.text:
vari = vari + 1;    // Equivalent of vari++; - Variable can be written to and so can go on the left-hand side



    pi = pi + 1;      // Equivalent of pi++; - Constant cannot be written to so cannot go on left-hand side

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
pi++;    // GM1026 Cannot increment a constant
// OR:
show_debug_message--; // GM1026 Cannot decrement a function name

In the code example, pi is a constant and cannot be changed by definition. show_debug_message() is a function and is not a number which can be incremented/decremented. If you want to perform these operations you must first ensure the value is assigned to a variable.
blocks.text: In the code example, pi is a constant and cannot be changed by definition. show_debug_message() is a function and is not a number which can be incremented/decremented. If you want to perform these operations you must first ensure the value is assigned to a variable.

blocks.html:
var _pi = pi;
_pi++;
blocks.text:
var _pi = pi;

    _pi++;

diagnostics.title: A string literal was unexpected at this time.

blocks.html: This message is shown when a string literal exists outside of a valid expression.
blocks.text: This message is shown when a string literal exists outside of a valid expression.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: "this is a string" // GM1027! A lone string!
blocks.text: "this is a string" // GM1027! A lone string!

blocks.html: The string literal should be assigned to a variable, or compared to a variable, or passed as an argument to a function call.
blocks.text: The string literal should be assigned to a variable, or compared to a variable, or passed as an argument to a function call.

blocks.html:
text = "this is a string";
if (text == "this is a string")
{
    show_debug_message("this is a string");
}

diagnostics.title: Accessor is intended for type of 'TYPE' but 'TYPE' appears instead.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you address an element of a data structure using the accessor syntax and don't use the right operator for the data structure's type. Each type of data structure has its own accessor symbol that is used with it. See Accessors for the full list.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you address an element of a data structure using the accessor syntax and don't use the right operator for the data structure's type. Each type of data structure has its own accessor symbol that is used with it. See Accessors for the full list.

blocks.html: Possible causes of this error can be:
blocks.text: Possible causes of this error can be:

blocks.html:
• You've accidentally used the wrong accessor for the type of data structure you're accessing.
  • You forgot the accessor symbol. In this case the lookup is interpreted as an array lookup.
blocks.text:
You've accidentally used the wrong accessor for the type of data structure you're accessing.
    You forgot the accessor symbol. In this case the lookup is interpreted as an array lookup.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
lst_instances = ds_list_create();
if (instance_place_list(x, y, obj_enemy, lst_instances, true))
{
    var _ins = lst_instances[? 0]; // GM1028! Wrong accessor
    show_debug_message($"The closest instance is {real(_ins)}.");
}

In the code example above, a DS list is populated with instances of an object obj_enemy. When there are any instances in the list, the first one is accessed. The pipe character | is for accessing DS lists, however the list is incorrectly accessed with a ?, which is for DS maps. Changing the operator fixes the issue by addressing the data structure using the correct accessor.
blocks.text: In the code example above, a DS list is populated with instances of an object obj_enemy. When there are any instances in the list, the first one is accessed. The pipe character | is for accessing DS lists, however the list is incorrectly accessed with a ?, which is for DS maps. Changing the operator fixes the issue by addressing the data structure using the correct accessor.

blocks.html:
lst_instances = ds_list_create();
if (instance_place_list(x, y, obj_enemy, lst_instances, true))
{
    var _ins = lst_instances[| 0]; // Good!
    show_debug_message($"The closest instance is {real(_ins)}.");
}

diagnostics.title: Potentially dangerous or unintended implicit cast from 'TYPE' to 'TYPE'.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you pass an argument to a function parameter whose type differs from the type expected, but can and will be converted to the expected. While legal, this tends to be unfavourable code as the runtime does its best guess as to how the data should be converted which may lead to unexpected bugs or errors. For example, passing the string "1234" to draw_sprite()'s 3rd parameter x is legal, the runtime will convert the String to the Real of the same value. However, if the string value could not convert to a type Real value then you would encounter a runtime error. The cast is implicit since the runtime does it for you instead of you calling the real() built-in function, and it's dangerous because it may or may not crash at runtime depending on how sanitary you keep your data.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you pass an argument to a function parameter whose type differs from the type expected, but can and will be converted to the expected. While legal, this tends to be unfavourable code as the runtime does its best guess as to how the data should be converted which may lead to unexpected bugs or errors. For example, passing the string "1234" to draw_sprite()'s 3rd parameter x is legal, the runtime will convert the String to the Real of the same value. However, if the string value could not convert to a type Real value then you would encounter a runtime error. The cast is implicit since the runtime does it for you instead of you calling the real() built-in function, and it's dangerous because it may or may not crash at runtime depending on how sanitary you keep your data.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _x = "1234";
var _y = "4321";
draw_sprite(sprite_index, image_index, _x, _y); // GM1029

The fix for this message is to either make the cast explicit using one of the built-in functions (e.g. string, real, etc.) or to rewrite the code so that you do not depend on the dangerous usage of that data type.
blocks.text: The fix for this message is to either make the cast explicit using one of the built-in functions (e.g. string, real, etc.) or to rewrite the code so that you do not depend on the dangerous usage of that data type.

blocks.html:
var _x = 1234;
var _y = y;
draw_sprite(sprite_index, image_index, _x, real(_y)); // Fix!

diagnostics.title: The identifier 'NAME' is reserved and cannot be used as a variable or macro name.

blocks.html: Some identifier names are reserved by the compiler and runtime and cannot be used in local or static variable declarations or in macro declarations. Keep in mind that in Constructor Function scopes some built-in variables are actually available for usage since they do not resolve to a built-in in those places. These tend to be built-in variables that modify some property of an Object such as sprite_index, or x and y.
blocks.text: Some identifier names are reserved by the compiler and runtime and cannot be used in local or static variable declarations or in macro declarations. Keep in mind that in Constructor Function scopes some built-in variables are actually available for usage since they do not resolve to a built-in in those places. These tend to be built-in variables that modify some property of an Object such as sprite_index, or x and y.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var image_index = 1; // GM1030
function SpriteData() constructor {
    var image_index = 1; // Good!
}
The fix is to find another, non-conflicting name to use for your variable instead.
blocks.text: The fix is to find another, non-conflicting name to use for your variable instead.

blocks.html:
var _image_index = 1; // Fix!
function SpriteData() constructor {
     var image_index = 1; // Good!
}

diagnostics.title: The name 'IDENTIFIER' is an asset or constant and cannot be assigned to.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you try to assign a value to an asset or a constant. Assets and constants cannot be changed and are meant to be used stand alone on the right-hand side of statements, in conditionals, or in expressions.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you try to assign a value to an asset or a constant. Assets and constants cannot be changed and are meant to be used stand alone on the right-hand side of statements, in conditionals, or in expressions.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
obj_control = 75; // GM1035! Cannot assign value to Asset type
pi = 1.618; // GM1035! Cannot assign value to constant
blocks.text:
obj_control = 75; // GM1035! Cannot assign value to Asset type

    pi = 1.618; // GM1035! Cannot assign value to constant

blocks.html: Depending on the intention, either the name of the variable to be assigned to can be changed or the asset or constant should be moved to the right-hand side of the assignment.
blocks.text: Depending on the intention, either the name of the variable to be assigned to can be changed or the asset or constant should be moved to the right-hand side of the assignment.

blocks.html:
control = 75;
value = pi;
blocks.text:
control = 75;

    value = pi;

diagnostics.title: No references to arguments INDEX, … but references argument INDEX

blocks.html: This message is shown when referencing an argument in a function via the argument0..argument15 built-in variables, and one or more indices have been skipped. While the arguments may be referenced in any order all indices 0..n must be referenced at least once; where n is the number of arguments in your function. If the code changes so that it no longer accesses e.g. argument0, all other arguments need to be changed; argument1 becomes argument0, argument2 becomes argument1, etc.
blocks.text: This message is shown when referencing an argument in a function via the argument0..argument15 built-in variables, and one or more indices have been skipped. While the arguments may be referenced in any order all indices 0..n must be referenced at least once; where n is the number of arguments in your function. If the code changes so that it no longer accesses e.g. argument0, all other arguments need to be changed; argument1 becomes argument0, argument2 becomes argument1, etc.

blocks.html: See: argument
blocks.text: See: argument

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function args() {
    var _x = argument0;
    var _y = argument2; // GM1032! Missing reference to argument1
}
Replace the argument# variable with the first unused argument# variable.
blocks.text: Replace the argument# variable with the first unused argument# variable.

blocks.html:
function args() {
    var _x = argument0;
    var _y = argument1; // Fix!
}

diagnostics.title: Possibly unintended or misplaced semicolon.

blocks.html: This message is shown when there is a semicolon in the code that might be unnecessary at that position.
blocks.text: This message is shown when there is a semicolon in the code that might be unnecessary at that position.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: var _a = 3434;;
The double semicolon is not needed and can be removed.
blocks.text: The double semicolon is not needed and can be removed.

blocks.html: var _a = 3434;

diagnostics.title: Argument cannot be referenced outside of script or function.

blocks.html: This message indicates that one of the built-in variables argument0 - argument15 or the built-in variable argument (argument[0], argument[1], etc.) has been referenced outside of the scope of a function or script. These built-in variables are only legal inside functions, i.e. inside the opening and closing curly braces.
blocks.text: This message indicates that one of the built-in variables argument0 - argument15 or the built-in variable argument (argument[0], argument[1], etc.) has been referenced outside of the scope of a function or script. These built-in variables are only legal inside functions, i.e. inside the opening and closing curly braces.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function args()
{
    
}
var _first_parameter = argument[0];
var _second_parameter = argument[1];
In this case the reference of the built-in variables is intended, they should be moved inside the curly braces. If the references aren't intended to be used, they should be removed.
blocks.text: In this case the reference of the built-in variables is intended, they should be moved inside the curly braces. If the references aren't intended to be used, they should be removed.

blocks.html:
function args()
{
    var _first_parameter = argument[0];
    var _second_parameter = argument[1];
}

diagnostics.title: Return type differs from previously established return type.

blocks.html: This message is shown when your JSDoc differs from the type returned in code or if Feather determines that you've returned multiple different non-compatible types from the same function. A non-compatible type would be something like Real, and String both being returned from the same function. Where something like Real, and Undefined might be compatible since undefined is commonly used to indicate no result. Returning different types of data is sometimes a valid strategy but it is typically dangerous since consuming code may assume that only one type of data will be returned, which may result in runtime errors or strange behaviour in the calling code.
blocks.text: This message is shown when your JSDoc differs from the type returned in code or if Feather determines that you've returned multiple different non-compatible types from the same function. A non-compatible type would be something like Real, and String both being returned from the same function. Where something like Real, and Undefined might be compatible since undefined is commonly used to indicate no result. Returning different types of data is sometimes a valid strategy but it is typically dangerous since consuming code may assume that only one type of data will be returned, which may result in runtime errors or strange behaviour in the calling code.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// @returns {real}
function get_random_number() {
    return "1"; // GM1035!
}
function get_random_number2() { // no JSDoc here
    if (irandom(100) < 50)
        return 0; // Return type is established here as 'Real'
    return "1"; // GM1035!
}
The fix for this is to either update your JSDoc accordingly, or to rewrite your code to ensure that the same type is returned from all return statements.
blocks.text: The fix for this is to either update your JSDoc accordingly, or to rewrite your code to ensure that the same type is returned from all return statements.

blocks.html:
/// @returns {string}
function get_random_number() {
    return "1"; // Fixed! But maybe rename the function!
}
function get_random_number2() { // no JSDoc here
    if (irandom(100) < 50)
        return 0; // Return type is established here as 'Real'
    return 1; // Fix!
}

diagnostics.title: Array cannot be indexed in this way.

blocks.html: This message is shown if you index into an array with either 0 indices, or too many indices for the dimensionality of the array. Keep in mind that the 2D array syntax is deprecated in favour of staggered array indexing.
blocks.text: This message is shown if you index into an array with either 0 indices, or too many indices for the dimensionality of the array. Keep in mind that the 2D array syntax is deprecated in favour of staggered array indexing.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function choose2d() {
    var _x = irandom(argument_count);
    var _y = irandom(argument_count);
    return argument[_x, _y]; // GM1036! argument array is not 2d
}
var _arr = [ 1, 2, 3, 4 ];
var _idx = _arr[]; // GM1036!
The fix for this issue is to either provide the index, or to rethink how you're accessing the array.
blocks.text: The fix for this issue is to either provide the index, or to rethink how you're accessing the array.

blocks.html:
function choose2d(_arr) {
    var _x = irandom(array_height_2d(_arr));
    var _y = irandom(array_length_2d(_arr));
    return _arr[_x, _y]; // Fix! Keep in mind this syntax is deprecated
}
var _arr = [ 1, 2, 3, 4 ];
var _idx = _arr[0]; // Fix!

diagnostics.title: Macro with this name has been previously declared.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you defined a macro with the same name before, somewhere in your code. Project-wide search (Ctrl+Alt+F) can be useful in this case to check how many occurrences of the macro are in your project. Look for #macro <macro_name> to find all definitions of this macro.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you defined a macro with the same name before, somewhere in your code. Project-wide search (Ctrl+Alt+F) can be useful in this case to check how many occurrences of the macro are in your project. Look for #macro <macro_name> to find all definitions of this macro.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Script Asset: Debug
#macro dbg show_debug_message

/// Script Asset: Utility
#macro dbg show_debug_message
Remove all duplicate macro definitions until there is one left.
blocks.text: Remove all duplicate macro definitions until there is one left.

blocks.html:
/// Script Asset: Debug
#macro dbg show_debug_message
blocks.text:
/// Script Asset: Debug

    #macro dbg show_debug_message

diagnostics.title: argument# and argument[#] referencing cannot be mixed.

blocks.html: This message indicates that the argument array variable and argument0 - argument15 variables are used together in a function. The former is used in functions that support a variable number of arguments, the latter is used when you know the number of arguments in advance. In any function, you should only ever use one of the two.
blocks.text: This message indicates that the argument array variable and argument0 - argument15 variables are used together in a function. The former is used in functions that support a variable number of arguments, the latter is used when you know the number of arguments in advance. In any function, you should only ever use one of the two.

blocks.html: See: argument
blocks.text: See: argument

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function func()
{
   var _a = argument0;
   var _b = argument[1];
}
Change all argument[n]/argumentn variables to the same type of referencing, depending on what's needed in the function.
blocks.text: Change all argument[n]/argumentn variables to the same type of referencing, depending on what's needed in the function.

blocks.html:
function func()
{
   var _a = argument0;
   var _b = argument1;
}
// OR:
function func()
{
   var _a = argument[0];
   var _b = argument[1];
}

diagnostics.title: The type 'TYPE' appears where the type 'TYPE' is expected.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you pass an argument to a function call's parameter of a different type. For example, passing a Id.Instance to a String parameter.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you pass an argument to a function call's parameter of a different type. For example, passing a Id.Instance to a String parameter.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: var _inst = instance_create_depth(x, y, -100, "obj_player"); // GM1041!
blocks.text: var _inst = instance_create_depth(x, y, -100, "obj_player"); // GM1041!

blocks.html: The fix is to determine what the correct type to pass to the parameter is, and rewrite your code accordingly.
blocks.text: The fix is to determine what the correct type to pass to the parameter is, and rewrite your code accordingly.

blocks.html: var _inst = instance_create_depth(x, y, -100, obj_player); // Fix!
blocks.text: var _inst = instance_create_depth(x, y, -100, obj_player); // Fix!

diagnostics.title: Parameter name 'PARAMETER' differs from 'PARAMETER' specified in jsdoc.

blocks.html: This message is shown when there is a difference between a function's parameter name in the JSDoc and its corresponding parameter name in the argument list. This could have a couple of causes:
blocks.text: This message is shown when there is a difference between a function's parameter name in the JSDoc and its corresponding parameter name in the argument list. This could have a couple of causes:

blocks.html:
• There is a typo in the variable name in the JSDoc or in the argument list.
  • You renamed the parameter name in the argument list but not in the JSDoc or vice versa.
blocks.text:
There is a typo in the variable name in the JSDoc or in the argument list.
    You renamed the parameter name in the argument list but not in the JSDoc or vice versa.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// @func sum(_v1, _v2);
/// @desc This function returns the sum of two 3-component vectors
/// @arg {Array<Real>} _v1 The first vector
/// @arg {Array<Real>} _v2 The second vector
function sum(_v, _v2)
{
    return [
        _v1[0] + _v2[0],
        _v1[1] + _v2[1],
        _v1[2] + _v2[2]
    ];
}
To fix this issue you need to change the incorrectly named variable to the correct one to make sure both names correspond.
blocks.text: To fix this issue you need to change the incorrectly named variable to the correct one to make sure both names correspond.

blocks.html:
/// @func sum(_v1, _v2);
/// @desc This function returns the sum of two 3-component vectors
/// @arg {Array<Real>} _v1 The first vector
/// @arg {Array<Real>} _v2 The second vector
function sum(_v1, _v2)
{
    return [
        _v1[0] + _v2[0],
        _v1[1] + _v2[1],
        _v1[2] + _v2[2]
    ];
}

diagnostics.title: Potentially unintentional type reassignment from '{0}' to '{1}'.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you assign a new value to an existing variable and the type of the new value is different from the type that the variable currently holds.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you assign a new value to an existing variable and the type of the new value is different from the type that the variable currently holds.

blocks.html: This may not cause any issues, though it could make it more difficult to interpret your GML code correctly when you use the same variable name multiple times.
blocks.text: This may not cause any issues, though it could make it more difficult to interpret your GML code correctly when you use the same variable name multiple times.

blocks.html: It is good practice to keep the data type that you store in a variable constant, even though GameMaker doesn't enforce this in any way.
blocks.text: It is good practice to keep the data type that you store in a variable constant, even though GameMaker doesn't enforce this in any way.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
// Store a real number in my_var
my_var = 5;

// Next store a string in my_var
my_var = "I'm a string";  // type reassignment!

This issue can be fixed in multiple ways, it depends on what you're trying to do in your code. If the string has a different purpose in your code you could store it in a different variable with an appropriate name.
blocks.text: This issue can be fixed in multiple ways, it depends on what you're trying to do in your code. If the string has a different purpose in your code you could store it in a different variable with an appropriate name.

blocks.html:
// Store a real number in my_var
my_var = 5;

// Store a new real number in my_var
my_var = 100;

// Store a string in a new variable my_string
my_string = "I'm a string";

diagnostics.title: Constant is expected to be one of the following: {0}

blocks.html: This message is shown whenever one constant from a group of constants is expected as an argument and you've provided a value that's not in that group. Examples of these groups of constants are the Mouse Button Constants, the Game Speed Constants and the Primitive Type Constants. A constant from another group or a real number may accidentally work but it is not good practice to use them. Using the right constant in the right place helps increase the readability of your code.
blocks.text: This message is shown whenever one constant from a group of constants is expected as an argument and you've provided a value that's not in that group. Examples of these groups of constants are the Mouse Button Constants, the Game Speed Constants and the Primitive Type Constants. A constant from another group or a real number may accidentally work but it is not good practice to use them. Using the right constant in the right place helps increase the readability of your code.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
// Example 1
if mouse_check_button_pressed(mb_midle)
{
}

// Example 2
if mouse_check_button_pressed(vk_left)
{
}
If this was caused by a typo, then fixing the typo fixes it. In other cases the constant needs to be changed to a valid one.
blocks.text: If this was caused by a typo, then fixing the typo fixes it. In other cases the constant needs to be changed to a valid one.

blocks.html:
// Example 1
if mouse_check_button_pressed(mb_middle)
{
}

// Example 2
if mouse_check_button_pressed(mb_left)
{
}

diagnostics.title: Type '{0}' differs from type '{1}' specified in jsdoc.

blocks.html: This message is shown when Feather detects that the type of a variable in your code doesn't correspond to the type the JSDoc says that variable should be.
blocks.text: This message is shown when Feather detects that the type of a variable in your code doesn't correspond to the type the JSDoc says that variable should be.

blocks.html: This can happen when you write the JSDoc already, but decide to change the code afterwards. In that case, the JSDoc will no longer be up to date and needs to be changed to reflect the changes.
blocks.text: This can happen when you write the JSDoc already, but decide to change the code afterwards. In that case, the JSDoc will no longer be up to date and needs to be changed to reflect the changes.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// @func return_something()
/// @desc This function returns something
///
/// @returns {Id.Instance} A new instance
///
function return_something()
{
    return "something";
}

In the code example above the JSDoc says the function returns an instance ID, but the code actually returns a string. If this is the intent, the type in the JSDoc needs to be changed to String to reflect that. If not, the code needs to be changed so it returns an instance.
blocks.text: In the code example above the JSDoc says the function returns an instance ID, but the code actually returns a string. If this is the intent, the type in the JSDoc needs to be changed to String to reflect that. If not, the code needs to be changed so it returns an instance.

blocks.html:
/// @func return_something()
/// @desc This function returns something
///
/// @returns {String} The string "something"
///
function return_something()
{
    return "something";
}

diagnostics.title: The identifier '{0}' is declared as a local variable and cannot be accessed in this way.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you attempt to access a local variable (defined with the var keyword) using the dot operator. The dot operator accesses a different scope, though local variables are already in the current scope.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you attempt to access a local variable (defined with the var keyword) using the dot operator. The dot operator accesses a different scope, though local variables are already in the current scope.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
var _condition = false;
if (self._condition)    // Error! Variable is local...
{
}
A local (or temporary) variable should always be used without a prefix that refers to a scope. The scope of local variables is always the current block of code.
blocks.text: A local (or temporary) variable should always be used without a prefix that refers to a scope. The scope of local variables is always the current block of code.

blocks.html:
var _condition = false;
if (_condition)
{
}

diagnostics.title: Macro expressions should not be terminated with a ';' semicolon.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you end a macro definition with a semicolon. Macros can go anywhere in your code and are replaced by their value. Any semicolons in the macro's value are also inserted and may end up in places where they cause a syntax error.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you end a macro definition with a semicolon. Macros can go anywhere in your code and are replaced by their value. Any semicolons in the macro's value are also inserted and may end up in places where they cause a syntax error.

blocks.html: See the section on Macros on the Constants page for more info.
blocks.text: See the section on Macros on the Constants page for more info.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
randomise();

#macro NEW_COLOR make_color_rgb(random(255), random(255), random(255));

draw_primitive_begin(pr_trianglelist);

repeat(3)
{
    draw_vertex_color(random(room_width), random(room_height), NEW_COLOR, 1);    // Issue!
}

draw_primitive_end();

Inserting the macro into the function call leads to a semicolon being inserted right after the third argument. This is incorrect, since this semicolon marks the end of the statement while the function call still needs an additional parameter and also has to be closed with a parenthesis. Removing the semicolon at the end of the macro fixes the issue.
blocks.text: Inserting the macro into the function call leads to a semicolon being inserted right after the third argument. This is incorrect, since this semicolon marks the end of the statement while the function call still needs an additional parameter and also has to be closed with a parenthesis. Removing the semicolon at the end of the macro fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
// The semicolon that gets inserted as part of the macro causes a syntax error:
// draw_vertex_color(random(room_width), random(room_height), make_color_rgb(random(255), random(255), random(255));, 1);
randomise();

#macro NEW_COLOR make_color_rgb(random(255), random(255), random(255))

draw_primitive_begin(pr_trianglelist);

repeat(3)
{
    draw_vertex_color(random(room_width), random(room_height), NEW_COLOR, 1);    // Fixed!
}

draw_primitive_end();

diagnostics.title: The delete operator can only act on a variable of type 'struct'.

blocks.html: The new and delete operators are specifically for use with structs. Instances are destroyed using instance_destroy(), arrays are garbage-collected once they're no longer referenced and other resource types have their own functions to handle deleting/freeing them (a *_destroy or *_free function).
blocks.text: The new and delete operators are specifically for use with structs. Instances are destroyed using instance_destroy(), arrays are garbage-collected once they're no longer referenced and other resource types have their own functions to handle deleting/freeing them (a *_destroy or *_free function).

blocks.html:
values = [2, 403, 202, 303, 773, 573];
delete values;
blocks.text:
values = [2, 403, 202, 303, 773, 573];

    delete values;

blocks.html: To fix this the appropriate function or method should be used which, for arrays, is setting the variable to undefined.
blocks.text: To fix this the appropriate function or method should be used which, for arrays, is setting the variable to undefined.

blocks.html: values = undefined;
blocks.text: values = undefined;

diagnostics.title: Cannot inherit from non-existent function '{0}'.

blocks.html: This message is shown when the constructor that a constructor is inheriting from doesn't exist. Possible causes are:
blocks.text: This message is shown when the constructor that a constructor is inheriting from doesn't exist. Possible causes are:

blocks.html:
• The constructor to inherit from still needs to be defined.
  • The function must be marked as a constructor by adding the constructor keyword.
  • There is a typo in the inherited constructor name.
blocks.text:
The constructor to inherit from still needs to be defined.
    The function must be marked as a constructor by adding the constructor keyword.
    There is a typo in the inherited constructor name.

blocks.html: See: Structs & Constructors
blocks.text: See: Structs & Constructors

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function vec2() : vec()
{
}

The code example above attempts to create an inherited constructor function, but some things are missing. First, the constructor to inherit from, vec, isn't defined yet. Second, the function isn't marked as a constructor with the constructor keyword. To fix the error the parent constructor should be defined and the constructor keyword be added to both.
blocks.text: The code example above attempts to create an inherited constructor function, but some things are missing. First, the constructor to inherit from, vec, isn't defined yet. Second, the function isn't marked as a constructor with the constructor keyword. To fix the error the parent constructor should be defined and the constructor keyword be added to both.

blocks.html:
function vec() constructor {}
function vec2() : vec() constructor
{
}

diagnostics.title: Cannot mix argument# and named parameters.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've used one of the argumentn variables while the function parameters are defined as named parameters. For every function either one or the other should be used.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've used one of the argumentn variables while the function parameters are defined as named parameters. For every function either one or the other should be used.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function func(_a, _b, _c) {
    show_debug_message($"{argument0}, {argument1}, {argument2}");
}

In the code example above the parameters are already defined as named parameters. Replacing the occurrences of argument0 - argument2 in the function body fixes this issue. argument0 is replaced with _a, argument1 is replaced with _b and argument2 is replaced with _c. So every argument is replaced with the named argument at the corresponding index.
blocks.text: In the code example above the parameters are already defined as named parameters. Replacing the occurrences of argument0 - argument2 in the function body fixes this issue. argument0 is replaced with _a, argument1 is replaced with _b and argument2 is replaced with _c. So every argument is replaced with the named argument at the corresponding index.

blocks.html:
function func(_a, _b, _c) {
    show_debug_message($"{_a}, {_b}, {_c}");
}

diagnostics.title: Bad practice to declare non-optional parameter after an optional parameter.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you list optional parameters before non-optional parameters. As a consequence, in order to use the default value of those optional parameters it's necessary to omit the argument. All optional parameters should go at the end of the parameter list.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you list optional parameters before non-optional parameters. As a consequence, in order to use the default value of those optional parameters it's necessary to omit the argument. All optional parameters should go at the end of the parameter list.

blocks.html: See the section on Optional Arguments on the Script Functions And Variables page.
blocks.text: See the section on Optional Arguments on the Script Functions And Variables page.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function func(arg1, arg2, arg3=7, arg4)
{
}
func(4, 5, , 8);  // the third parameter has to be omitted to use the default value
This can be fixed by changing the order of the function parameters such that all optional parameters and their default values go at the end of the parameter list.
blocks.text: This can be fixed by changing the order of the function parameters such that all optional parameters and their default values go at the end of the parameter list.

blocks.html:
function func(arg1, arg2, arg4, arg3=7)
{
}
func(4, 5, 8);

diagnostics.title: Cannot 'new' the identifier '{0}' as it is not a constructor function.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you try to call the new operator with a valid function name that's not marked as a constructor.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you try to call the new operator with a valid function name that's not marked as a constructor.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function item()
{
}
sword = new item();
In order to fix this error the constructor keyword must be added to the function definition.
blocks.text: In order to fix this error the constructor keyword must be added to the function definition.

blocks.html:
function item() constructor
{
}
sword = new item();

diagnostics.title: The parameter '{0}' has been previously declared.

blocks.html: This message is shown when the same parameter name occurs multiple times in a function's parameter list.
blocks.text: This message is shown when the same parameter name occurs multiple times in a function's parameter list.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
function func(_param1, _param2, _param1)
{
}
Depending on what is intended, the parameter should either be removed or renamed.
