blocks.text: Depending on what is intended, the parameter should either be removed or renamed.

blocks.html:
// Option 1: Remove double
function func(_param1, _param2)
{
}
// Option 2: Rename the parameter
function func(_param1, _param2, _param3)
{
}

diagnostics.title: Dangerous call to variable of type '{0}'.

blocks.html: Shown when you try to call something that is not a function.
blocks.text: Shown when you try to call something that is not a function.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
my_function = 100;
my_function();
my_function = pi;
my_function();

diagnostics.title: Malformed type '{0}' in jsdoc.

blocks.html: This message indicates that Feather is unable to parse a parameter or return type in the function's JSDoc. The supported syntax is given on the Feather Data Types page.
blocks.text: This message indicates that Feather is unable to parse a parameter or return type in the function's JSDoc. The supported syntax is given on the Feather Data Types page.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// @function func(_param1, _param2, _param3)
/// @desc This function does something
/// @param {Array[String} _param1 This is parameter 1
/// @param {String Array[String]} _param2 This is parameter 2
/// @param {Id Instance} _param3 This is parameter 3
function func(_param1, _param2, _param3)
{
    show_debug_message("The parameters are: {0}, {1} and {2}", _param1, _param2, _param3);
}
The JSDoc types in the code example above can be corrected as follows:
blocks.text: The JSDoc types in the code example above can be corrected as follows:

blocks.html:
/// @function func(_param1, _param2, _param3)
/// @desc This function does something
/// @param {Array[String]} _param1 This is parameter 1
/// @param {String,Array[String]} _param2 This is parameter 2
/// @param {Id.Instance} _param3 This is parameter 3
function func(_param1, _param2, _param3)
{
    show_debug_message("The parameters are: {0}, {1} and {2}", _param1, _param2, _param3);
}

diagnostics.title: Ternary may yield differing types '{0}' and '{1}'.

blocks.html: This message is shown when a ternary operator returns a type of value in the true case that's different from the type in the false case or vice versa. As a consequence, the variable that's assigned to may receive a different type, depending on the outcome of the condition.
blocks.text: This message is shown when a ternary operator returns a type of value in the true case that's different from the type in the false case or vice versa. As a consequence, the variable that's assigned to may receive a different type, depending on the outcome of the condition.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
tex = (texture_defined) ? sprite_get_texture(sprite_index, 0) : -1;

/// Draw Event
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, tex);
This can be fixed by explicitly converting the type returned in one of the cases to the type of the other case.
blocks.text: This can be fixed by explicitly converting the type returned in one of the cases to the type of the other case.

diagnostics.title: Redeclaration of global function '{0}' originally declared in '{1}'.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've already declared a global function with the same name in another script asset.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've already declared a global function with the same name in another script asset.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Script1
function make_game()
{
}

/// Script2
function make_game()
{
}

One of the function definitions should be removed so that only one remains in the global namespace. If you want to create two functions with the same name then it is possible to create them as static functions within two different functions. The functions in which you define the static functions then act as a namespace.
blocks.text: One of the function definitions should be removed so that only one remains in the global namespace. If you want to create two functions with the same name then it is possible to create them as static functions within two different functions. The functions in which you define the static functions then act as a namespace.

blocks.html:
/// Script1
function make_game()
{
}

diagnostics.title: Syntax Error

blocks.html: This message indicates a general syntax error in your code. Syntax errors cover a range of possible errors related to the syntax of your code.
blocks.text: This message indicates a general syntax error in your code. Syntax errors cover a range of possible errors related to the syntax of your code.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _this * something;
= 48;
blocks.text:
var _this * something;

    = 48;

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_blendmode(bm_normal) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you change the blend mode to a value different from bm_normal with a call to gpu_set_blendmode but don't change it back to bm_normal afterwards. After drawing something with a different blend mode it is important to set blending back to normal so everything that's drawn after it is drawn correctly.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you change the blend mode to a value different from bm_normal with a call to gpu_set_blendmode but don't change it back to bm_normal afterwards. After drawing something with a different blend mode it is important to set blending back to normal so everything that's drawn after it is drawn correctly.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_blendmode(bm_add);
draw_self();

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, $"Score: {score}");

The code in the example intends to draw an instance with added blending in its normal Draw event and some text with normal blending in its Draw GUI event. However, no call to reset the blend mode back to bm_normal is made in the Draw event and so the text in the Draw GUI event is also drawn using additive blending. Another call to gpu_set_blendmode needs to be added at the end of the Draw event to reset the blending back to bm_normal.
blocks.text: The code in the example intends to draw an instance with added blending in its normal Draw event and some text with normal blending in its Draw GUI event. However, no call to reset the blend mode back to bm_normal is made in the Draw event and so the text in the Draw GUI event is also drawn using additive blending. Another call to gpu_set_blendmode needs to be added at the end of the Draw event to reset the blending back to bm_normal.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_blendmode(bm_add);
draw_self();
gpu_set_blendmode(bm_normal);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, $"Score: {score}");

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call shader_reset() before end of script.

blocks.html: This error is shown when a call to the function shader_reset is missing after drawing using a custom shader (set with shader_set). When the shader isn't set back to the default shader after drawing using a custom shader, everything that's drawn after that is also drawn using that shader.
blocks.text: This error is shown when a call to the function shader_reset is missing after drawing using a custom shader (set with shader_set). When the shader isn't set back to the default shader after drawing using a custom shader, everything that's drawn after that is also drawn using that shader.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
shader_set(sh_fancy_lighting);
vertex_submit(vb_my_world_model, pr_trianglelist, -1);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "World 1");  // Also drawn using sh_fancy_lighting
The call to shader_set should be accompanied with a call to shader_reset.
blocks.text: The call to shader_set should be accompanied with a call to shader_reset.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
shader_set(sh_fancy_lighting);
vertex_submit(vb_my_world_model, pr_trianglelist, -1);
shader_reset();

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "World 1");

diagnostics.title: This for statement does not use its index and can be written as a repeat statement instead.

blocks.html: This message indicates that the for statement has a loop counter that is never used, e.g. to index an array. When the number of iterations is known in advance and doesn't depend on a condition the for loop doesn't need a counter and can be replaced by a repeat statement.
blocks.text: This message indicates that the for statement has a loop counter that is never used, e.g. to index an array. When the number of iterations is known in advance and doesn't depend on a condition the for loop doesn't need a counter and can be replaced by a repeat statement.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
randomise();
var _num_elements = 20;
array = [];

for(var i = 0;i < _num_elements;i++)
{
    array_push(array, irandom(100));
}

The for loop in the example code above doesn't use its index. In this specific situation, the function used (array_push()) automatically appends to the end of the array so the index doesn't have to be provided explicitly.
blocks.text: The for loop in the example code above doesn't use its index. In this specific situation, the function used (array_push()) automatically appends to the end of the array so the index doesn't have to be provided explicitly.

blocks.html:
randomise();
var _num_elements = 20;
array = [];

repeat(_num_elements)
{
    array_push(array, irandom(100));
}

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call surface_reset_target() before end of script.

blocks.html: This error indicates that you changed the draw target with a call to surface_set_target but haven't set it back with a call to surface_reset_target in all situations.
blocks.text: This error indicates that you changed the draw target with a call to surface_set_target but haven't set it back with a call to surface_reset_target in all situations.

blocks.html: See: Surfaces
blocks.text: See: Surfaces

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
if (!surface_exists(sf_canvas))
{
    sf_canvas = surface_create(512, 512);
}

surface_set_target(sf_canvas);
draw_clear_alpha(c_white, 0);
draw_rectangle(4, 4, 40, 40);

In the example code above the drawing target is still set to sf_canvas after the block of code has executed. Further draw commands will also draw to this surface. A call to surface_reset_target() is needed at the end to reset the drawing target.
blocks.text: In the example code above the drawing target is still set to sf_canvas after the block of code has executed. Further draw commands will also draw to this surface. A call to surface_reset_target() is needed at the end to reset the drawing target.

if (!surface_exists(sf_canvas))
{
    sf_canvas = surface_create(512, 512);
}

surface_set_target(sf_canvas);
draw_clear_alpha(c_white, 0);
draw_rectangle(4, 4, 40, 40);
surface_reset_target();

blocks.text: This message indicates that a semicolon ; is missing at the end of a var statement. Local variables can be declared without immediately assigning them a value, but this declaration needs to be terminated with a semicolon.

diagnostics.title: Opening another vertex batch before closing a previous vertex batch.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you start another vertex batch with a call to vertex_begin before having called vertex_end for the current batch. Every call to vertex_begin() must be followed by a call to vertex_end() before a next call to vertex_begin().
blocks.text: This message is shown when you start another vertex batch with a call to vertex_begin before having called vertex_end for the current batch. Every call to vertex_begin() must be followed by a call to vertex_end() before a next call to vertex_begin().

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
vertex_begin(vb, format);

// vertex_position_3d(...)
// vertex_color(...)
// vertex_texcoord(...)
// etc.
vertex_begin(vb, format);    // Error!

// vertex_position_3d(...)
// vertex_color(...)
// vertex_texcoord(...)
// etc.
vertex_end(vb);
In the example above two calls to vertex_begin() follow each other without a call to vertex_end() between them. Adding a call to vertex_end() in between fixes the issue.
blocks.text: In the example above two calls to vertex_begin() follow each other without a call to vertex_end() between them. Adding a call to vertex_end() in between fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
vertex_begin(vb, format);
// vertex_position_3d(...)
// vertex_color(...)
// vertex_texcoord(...)
// etc.
vertex_end(vb);              // End the current one first!

vertex_begin(vb, format);    // Only then start a new one!
// vertex_position_3d(...)
// vertex_color(...)
// vertex_texcoord(...)
// etc.
vertex_end(vb);

diagnostics.title: Closing a vertex batch without opening a vertex batch.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you close a vertex batch with a call to vertex_end before starting the batch with a call to vertex_begin. You first need to start the vertex batch with a call to vertex_begin(), then add vertex data according to the vertex format for the desired number of vertices and finally close the batch with a call to vertex_end().
blocks.text: This message is shown when you close a vertex batch with a call to vertex_end before starting the batch with a call to vertex_begin. You first need to start the vertex batch with a call to vertex_begin(), then add vertex data according to the vertex format for the desired number of vertices and finally close the batch with a call to vertex_end().

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: vertex_end(vb);
blocks.text: vertex_end(vb);

blocks.html: In the example code above a vertex batch is closed using vertex_end() without ever being opened. The fix is to add a call to vertex_begin() and add data for the vertices before the call to vertex_end().
blocks.text: In the example code above a vertex batch is closed using vertex_end() without ever being opened. The fix is to add a call to vertex_begin() and add data for the vertices before the call to vertex_end().

blocks.html:
vertex_begin(vb, format);
// vertex_position_3d(...)
// vertex_color(...)
// vertex_texcoord(...)
// etc.
vertex_end(vb);

diagnostics.title: The function '{0}' cannot be called outside of a vertex_begin()/vertex_end() block.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you're attempting to call a function that writes vertex data outside of vertex_begin / vertex_end. Vertex data can only be added after first calling vertex_begin() and before calling vertex_end().
blocks.text: This message is shown when you're attempting to call a function that writes vertex data outside of vertex_begin / vertex_end. Vertex data can only be added after first calling vertex_begin() and before calling vertex_end().

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
format = vertex_format_end();
vb = vertex_create_buffer();

vertex_begin(vb, format);
vertex_end(vb);
vertex_position_3d(vb, x, y, 0);
vertex_position_3d(vb, x + 100, y, 0);
vertex_position_3d(vb, x, y + 100, 0);
In the code example above, the function calls to write positions to the vertex buffer come after vertex_end(). To fix this they need to be moved between vertex_begin() and vertex_end().
blocks.text: In the code example above, the function calls to write positions to the vertex buffer come after vertex_end(). To fix this they need to be moved between vertex_begin() and vertex_end().

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
format = vertex_format_end();
vb = vertex_create_buffer();

vertex_begin(vb, format);
vertex_position_3d(vb, x, y, 0);
vertex_position_3d(vb, x + 100, y, 0);
vertex_position_3d(vb, x, y + 100, 0);
vertex_end(vb);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call vertex_end() before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you started writing vertex data to a vertex buffer but haven't properly finished writing the data with a closing call to vertex_end. Every call to vertex_begin should be accompanied by a call to vertex_end. To write data to a vertex buffer you should do the following:
blocks.text: This message indicates that you started writing vertex data to a vertex buffer but haven't properly finished writing the data with a closing call to vertex_end. Every call to vertex_begin should be accompanied by a call to vertex_end. To write data to a vertex buffer you should do the following:

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vb = vertex_create_buffer();
vertex_begin(vb, format);
vertex_position_3d(vb, 0, 0, 0);
vertex_colour(vb, c_white, 1);
// Etc.

/// Draw Event
vertex_submit(vb, pr_pointlist, -1);
In the code example above, the vertex buffer isn't properly finished because a call to vertex_end() is missing. This needs to be added to fix the issue.
blocks.text: In the code example above, the vertex buffer isn't properly finished because a call to vertex_end() is missing. This needs to be added to fix the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vb = vertex_create_buffer();
vertex_begin(vb, format);
vertex_position_3d(vb, 0, 0, 0);
vertex_colour(vb, c_white, 1);
// Etc.
vertex_end(vb);

/// Draw Event
vertex_submit(vb, pr_pointlist, -1);

diagnostics.title: Opening another vertex format before closing a previous vertex format.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you begin a new vertex format with vertex_format_begin before finishing the previous one with a call to vertex_format_end. A vertex format must always be closed before starting a new one.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you begin a new vertex format with vertex_format_begin before finishing the previous one with a call to vertex_format_end. A vertex format must always be closed before starting a new one.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
format1 = vertex_format_end();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
vertex_format_add_texcoord();
format2 = vertex_format_end();

In the example code above, one vertex format definition is nested inside another one. As a result, a vertex format is being defined while another one's definition hasn't finished. To fix this, all vertex formats should be defined one after the other:
blocks.text: In the example code above, one vertex format definition is nested inside another one. As a result, a vertex format is being defined while another one's definition hasn't finished. To fix this, all vertex formats should be defined one after the other:

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
format1 = vertex_format_end();

vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
vertex_format_add_texcoord();
format2 = vertex_format_end();

diagnostics.title: Closing a vertex format without opening a vertex format.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you close a vertex format with vertex_format_end without first having called vertex_format_begin.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you close a vertex format with vertex_format_end without first having called vertex_format_begin.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
format = vertex_format_end();
blocks.text:
/// Create Event

    format = vertex_format_end();

blocks.html: The code example above closes the vertex format without ever having started it with a call to vertex_format_begin(). The vertex format should be opened with a call to this function and at least one vertex attribute should be added to it using one of the vertex_format_add_* functions.
blocks.text: The code example above closes the vertex format without ever having started it with a call to vertex_format_begin(). The vertex format should be opened with a call to this function and at least one vertex attribute should be added to it using one of the vertex_format_add_* functions.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
format = vertex_format_end();

diagnostics.title: The function '{0}' cannot be called outside of a vertex_format_begin()/vertex_format_end() block.

blocks.html: The vertex_format_add_* functions can only be called between a call to vertex_format_begin and vertex_format_end. The function vertex_format_begin() starts the vertex format, calls to vertex_format_add_* define the vertex format's attributes and the function vertex_format_end() ends the definition of the vertex format and returns it.
blocks.text: The vertex_format_add_* functions can only be called between a call to vertex_format_begin and vertex_format_end. The function vertex_format_begin() starts the vertex format, calls to vertex_format_add_* define the vertex format's attributes and the function vertex_format_end() ends the definition of the vertex format and returns it.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
vertex_format_add_colour();
vertex_format_add_texcoord();
vertex_format_begin();
format = vertex_format_end();

In the code example above, the vertex_format_add_* functions are called before the call to vertex_format_begin() that begins the actual definition of a vertex format. These functions always go between vertex_format_begin() and vertex_format_end(). Moving the call to vertex_format_begin() before the first vertex_format_add_* call fixes the issue.
blocks.text: In the code example above, the vertex_format_add_* functions are called before the call to vertex_format_begin() that begins the actual definition of a vertex format. These functions always go between vertex_format_begin() and vertex_format_end(). Moving the call to vertex_format_begin() before the first vertex_format_add_* call fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
vertex_format_add_colour();
vertex_format_add_texcoord();
format = vertex_format_end();

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call vertex_format_end() before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you started the definition of a vertex format with vertex_format_begin but haven't finished it with a call to vertex_format_end. The call to vertex_format_end() returns the actual vertex format.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you started the definition of a vertex format with vertex_format_begin but haven't finished it with a call to vertex_format_end. The call to vertex_format_end() returns the actual vertex format.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
vertex_format_add_colour();
vertex_format_add_texcoord();
A vertex format definition isn't complete without a call to vertex_format_end() that returns the format. This needs to be added to fix the issue.
blocks.text: A vertex format definition isn't complete without a call to vertex_format_end() that returns the format. This needs to be added to fix the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
vertex_format_begin();
vertex_format_add_position_3d();
vertex_format_add_colour();
vertex_format_add_texcoord();
format = vertex_format_end();

diagnostics.title: Instance variable '{0}' declared outside of Create event, declare with 'var' or move to Create event.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you declare an instance variable outside of the Create event. Instance variables should always be created in the Create event to guarantee that you'll be able to access them in all other events.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you declare an instance variable outside of the Create event. Instance variables should always be created in the Create event to guarantee that you'll be able to access them in all other events.

blocks.html: When you don't define instance variables in the Create event, you might at one point run into a situation where that variable doesn't exist yet. For example, when you first define the instance variable in the Step event and only use it in the Step event, this won't cause problems. Though when you later decide to add a Begin Step event to the object and attempt to access the variable there, an error will be thrown when your game runs. This is because Begin Step events run before Step events and the first Step event hasn't run yet when the first Begin Step event runs.
blocks.text: When you don't define instance variables in the Create event, you might at one point run into a situation where that variable doesn't exist yet. For example, when you first define the instance variable in the Step event and only use it in the Step event, this won't cause problems. Though when you later decide to add a Begin Step event to the object and attempt to access the variable there, an error will be thrown when your game runs. This is because Begin Step events run before Step events and the first Step event hasn't run yet when the first Begin Step event runs.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
ammo_initialised = false;

/// Begin Step Event

/// Step Event
if (!ammo_initialised)
{
    ammo = 0;
    ammo_initialised = true;
}
var _ins_ammo = instance_place(x, y, obj_ammo);
if (_ins_ammo != noone)
{
    // Collect ammo
    ammo++;
    instance_destroy(_ins_ammo);
}
This issue is fixed by moving the declaration of the variable to the object's Create event.
blocks.text: This issue is fixed by moving the declaration of the variable to the object's Create event.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
ammo = 0;

/// Begin Step Event
// Do something with ammo here

/// Step Event
var _ins_ammo = instance_place(x, y, obj_ammo);
if (_ins_ammo != noone)
{
    // Collect ammo
    ammo++;
    instance_destroy(_ins_ammo);
}

diagnostics.title: Inconsistent naming. Recommended name is '{0}'.

blocks.html: This message is shown when Feather encounters a name in your code that's not named according to the naming rules as defined under Feather Settings > Naming Rules. The names can be asset names, names of variables in a particular scope (local, instance, etc.) as well as function, constructor, enum and macro names.
blocks.text: This message is shown when Feather encounters a name in your code that's not named according to the naming rules as defined under Feather Settings > Naming Rules. The names can be asset names, names of variables in a particular scope (local, instance, etc.) as well as function, constructor, enum and macro names.

blocks.html: Note that Feather will check against your own naming rules when you customise them in the Feather Preferences.
blocks.text: Note that Feather will check against your own naming rules when you customise them in the Feather Preferences.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var s = sprSprite;
enum size
{
    small,
    medium,
    large
}

function Show()
{
    show_debug_message("Here it is!");
}

The code in the example above contains a few names that aren't named according to Feather's default naming rules. To make them consistent with these rules, the code should be changed to the following:
blocks.text: The code in the example above contains a few names that aren't named according to Feather's default naming rules. To make them consistent with these rules, the code should be changed to the following:

blocks.html:
var _s = spr_sprite;
enum SIZE
{
    SMALL,
    MEDIUM,
    LARGE
}

function show()
{
    show_debug_message("Here it is!");
}

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call draw_set_valign(fa_top) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This warning message indicates that you changed the vertical text alignment to a value different from the default (fa_top) but haven't changed it back afterwards.
blocks.text: This warning message indicates that you changed the vertical text alignment to a value different from the default (fa_top) but haven't changed it back afterwards.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw GUI Begin Event
draw_set_valign(fa_bottom);
draw_text(5, room_height-5, "In the bottom-left corner");

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "In the top-left corner");

In the above code example, the vertical text alignment is set to bottom-aligned and some text is drawn in the Draw GUI Begin event. The text alignment isn't reset to fa_top, however, which causes text in the Draw GUI Event that follows it to be drawn mostly offscreen. This is because it is drawn bottom-aligned at a position in the top-left corner of the window. Resetting the vertical text alignment back to fa_top fixes the issue.
blocks.text: In the above code example, the vertical text alignment is set to bottom-aligned and some text is drawn in the Draw GUI Begin event. The text alignment isn't reset to fa_top, however, which causes text in the Draw GUI Event that follows it to be drawn mostly offscreen. This is because it is drawn bottom-aligned at a position in the top-left corner of the window. Resetting the vertical text alignment back to fa_top fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Draw GUI Begin Event
draw_set_valign(fa_bottom);
draw_text(5, room_height-5, "In the bottom-left corner");
draw_set_valign(fa_top);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "In the top-left corner");

diagnostics.title: all cannot be referenced in this way.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you attempt to reference the keyword all in the dot operator. The keyword all can be used in a with statement to indicate that it should loop through all instances, but it cannot be used with the dot operator to change a variable in all instances at the same time.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you attempt to reference the keyword all in the dot operator. The keyword all can be used in a with statement to indicate that it should loop through all instances, but it cannot be used with the dot operator to change a variable in all instances at the same time.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: all.x = 200;
blocks.text: all.x = 200;

blocks.html: The fix for this issue is to use the keyword all in a with statement.
blocks.text: The fix for this issue is to use the keyword all in a with statement.

blocks.html:
with (all)
{
    x = 200;
}

diagnostics.title: Return value of a pure function is not being used.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've called a pure function, which doesn't change anything and only returns a value, without using its return value. The return value can be used by assigning it to a variable, using it in an expression or by passing it as a parameter in a function call.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've called a pure function, which doesn't change anything and only returns a value, without using its return value. The return value can be used by assigning it to a variable, using it in an expression or by passing it as a parameter in a function call.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
variable_get_hash("member");
choose("a", "b", "c");
make_colour_rgb(255, 255, 0);
The return value needs be used in the code in order to fix the issue.
blocks.text: The return value needs be used in the code in order to fix the issue.

blocks.html:
var _hash = variable_get_hash("member");
if (choose("a", "b", "c") == "a") { show_debug_message("Good choice!"); }
draw_set_colour(make_colour_rgb(255, 255, 0));

diagnostics.title: Evaluation order of function calls in argument list not guaranteed between platforms.

blocks.html: This message is shown when there are multiple function calls in the argument list when calling a function. When a function is called, the arguments are not necessarily initialised in the order they're defined in the argument list. As a consequence, when the arguments contain function calls, those function calls may not execute in the order you'd expect. In some specific cases, such as when a function reads data sequentially, this can give unexpected results.
blocks.text: This message is shown when there are multiple function calls in the argument list when calling a function. When a function is called, the arguments are not necessarily initialised in the order they're defined in the argument list. As a consequence, when the arguments contain function calls, those function calls may not execute in the order you'd expect. In some specific cases, such as when a function reads data sequentially, this can give unexpected results.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
vertex_position_3d(vb, buffer_read(buff, buffer_f32), buffer_read(buff, buffer_f32), buffer_read(buff, buffer_f32));
/// z will be x, y will be y, x will be z
/// since the buffer_read's are called in order last to first

To make sure the assignments are done in the correct order you call the functions and assign the result of each of them to a temporary variable before calling the actual function. Then call the actual function and pass the temporary variables as the arguments.
blocks.text: To make sure the assignments are done in the correct order you call the functions and assign the result of each of them to a temporary variable before calling the actual function. Then call the actual function and pass the temporary variables as the arguments.

blocks.html:
var _x = buffer_read(buff, buffer_f32);
var _y = buffer_read(buff, buffer_f32);
var _z = buffer_read(buff, buffer_f32);
vertex_position_3d(vb, _x, _y, _z);

diagnostics.title: Reference to non-existent event '{0}'.

blocks.html: Shown when a user event is called but that user event does not exist in the object.
blocks.text: Shown when a user event is called but that user event does not exist in the object.

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call draw_set_halign(fa_left) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you changed the horizontal text alignment to a value different from the default (fa_left) but haven't changed it back afterwards.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you changed the horizontal text alignment to a value different from the default (fa_left) but haven't changed it back afterwards.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw GUI Begin Event
draw_set_halign(fa_right);
draw_text(room_width-5, 5, "In the top-right corner");

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "In the top-left corner");

In the example code above, the horizontal text alignment is set to right-aligned and some text is drawn in the Draw GUI Begin event. However, the text alignment isn't reset to fa_left, which causes text in the Draw GUI Event that follows it to be drawn mostly offscreen. This is because it is drawn right-aligned at a position in the top-left corner of the window. Resetting the horizontal text alignment back to fa_left fixes the issue.
blocks.text: In the example code above, the horizontal text alignment is set to right-aligned and some text is drawn in the Draw GUI Begin event. However, the text alignment isn't reset to fa_left, which causes text in the Draw GUI Event that follows it to be drawn mostly offscreen. This is because it is drawn right-aligned at a position in the top-left corner of the window. Resetting the horizontal text alignment back to fa_left fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Draw GUI Begin Event
draw_set_halign(fa_right);
draw_text(room_width-5, 5, "In the top-right corner");
draw_set_halign(fa_left);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "In the top-left corner");

diagnostics.title: Opening another primitive before closing a previous primitive.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you open another primitive using draw_primitive_begin without closing the current primitive with a call to draw_primitive_end.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you open another primitive using draw_primitive_begin without closing the current primitive with a call to draw_primitive_end.

blocks.html: A primitive is always drawn with a call to draw_primitive_begin(), followed by multiple calls to one of the draw_vertex* functions and finally a call to draw_primitive_end().
blocks.text: A primitive is always drawn with a call to draw_primitive_begin(), followed by multiple calls to one of the draw_vertex* functions and finally a call to draw_primitive_end().

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_primitive_begin(pr_linestrip);
draw_vertex(0, 0);
draw_vertex(10, 0);
draw_vertex(0, 10);
draw_primitive_begin(pr_linestrip);
draw_vertex(10, 0);
draw_vertex(20, 0);
draw_vertex(10, 10);
draw_primitive_end();
The first primitive is missing a draw_primitive_end() call after the calls to draw_vertex(). Adding it fixes the issue.
blocks.text: The first primitive is missing a draw_primitive_end() call after the calls to draw_vertex(). Adding it fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_primitive_begin(pr_linestrip);
draw_vertex(0, 0);
draw_vertex(10, 0);
draw_vertex(0, 10);
draw_primitive_end();

draw_primitive_begin(pr_linestrip);
draw_vertex(10, 0);
draw_vertex(20, 0);
draw_vertex(10, 10);
draw_primitive_end();

diagnostics.title: Closing a primitive without opening a primitive.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you made a call to draw_primitive_end to close a primitive, but haven't opened a primitive first with a call to draw_primitive_begin.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you made a call to draw_primitive_end to close a primitive, but haven't opened a primitive first with a call to draw_primitive_begin.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_primitive_end();  // Which primitive to close?
blocks.text:
/// Draw Event

    draw_primitive_end();  // Which primitive to close?

blocks.html: Calling draw_primitive_begin() before draw_primitive_end() fixes this issue.
blocks.text: Calling draw_primitive_begin() before draw_primitive_end() fixes this issue.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_primitive_begin(pr_linelist);

// draw_vertex, draw_vertex_colour, etc.

draw_primitive_end();

diagnostics.title: The function '{0}' cannot be called outside of a draw_primitive_begin()/draw_primitive_end() block.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you use one of the draw_vertex* functions outside of  draw_primitive_begin / draw_primitive_end. These functions add vertices when drawing a primitive and only do something when called between draw_primitive_begin() and draw_primitive_end().
blocks.text: This message is shown when you use one of the draw_vertex* functions outside of draw_primitive_begin / draw_primitive_end. These functions add vertices when drawing a primitive and only do something when called between draw_primitive_begin() and draw_primitive_end().

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_vertex(room_width/4, room_height/4);
draw_vertex(room_width/2, room_height/4);
draw_vertex(room_width/4, room_height/2);
draw_primitive_begin(pr_trianglelist);
draw_primitive_end();
In the code example, the calls to draw_vertex() need to be moved between the calls to draw_primitive_begin() and draw_primitive_end().
blocks.text: In the code example, the calls to draw_vertex() need to be moved between the calls to draw_primitive_begin() and draw_primitive_end().

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_primitive_begin(pr_trianglelist);
draw_vertex(room_width/4, room_height/4);
draw_vertex(room_width/2, room_height/4);
draw_vertex(room_width/4, room_height/2);
draw_primitive_end();

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call draw_primitive_end() before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that a call to draw_primitive_end is missing in at least one place in your code. This can happen when you draw, for example, different vertices based on an if-else condition and you added the call to draw_primitive_end() to the if case, but not to the else case.
blocks.text: This message indicates that a call to draw_primitive_end is missing in at least one place in your code. This can happen when you draw, for example, different vertices based on an if-else condition and you added the call to draw_primitive_end() to the if case, but not to the else case.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
var _condition = (irandom(100) < 50);
draw_primitive_begin(pr_linelist);

if (_condition)
{
    // draw_vertex, draw_vertex_colour, etc.
    draw_primitive_end();
}
else
{
    // draw_vertex, draw_vertex_colour, etc.
}

In the example above one of two possible code paths is followed, where each draws a different shape. The if case ends with a call to draw_primitive_end(), though the else case is missing that call. Adding it to the else case is one possible fix, though the clean and more robust way to fix the issue is to move it outside of the if-else statement.
blocks.text: In the example above one of two possible code paths is followed, where each draws a different shape. The if case ends with a call to draw_primitive_end(), though the else case is missing that call. Adding it to the else case is one possible fix, though the clean and more robust way to fix the issue is to move it outside of the if-else statement.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
var _condition = (irandom(100) < 50);
draw_primitive_begin(pr_linelist);

if (_condition)
{
    // draw_vertex, draw_vertex_colour, etc.
}
else
{
    // draw_vertex, draw_vertex_colour, etc.
}

draw_primitive_end();  // Call no longer depends on if-else condition!

diagnostics.title: Opening another File Find before closing a previous File Find.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you start another File Find with file_find_first without closing the previous one with file_find_close. You can only perform one File Find at a time and one needs to be closed before another can be opened.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you start another File Find with file_find_first without closing the previous one with file_find_close. You can only perform one File Find at a time and one needs to be closed before another can be opened.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
var _look_for_description = true;
var _file = file_find_first("/game_data/*.bin", fa_none);
if (_look_for_description)
{
    _file2 = file_find_first("/game_data/*.json", fa_none);
}

file_find_close();

In the code example above a second file find is started with file_find_first() before the current file find is properly closed if a variable _look_for_description is set to true. To properly fix the issue the first file find needs to be closed before the if statement is checked and the second file find needs to be closed inside the true case of the if statement (at the same level as the call to file_find_first()).
blocks.text: In the code example above a second file find is started with file_find_first() before the current file find is properly closed if a variable _look_for_description is set to true. To properly fix the issue the first file find needs to be closed before the if statement is checked and the second file find needs to be closed inside the true case of the if statement (at the same level as the call to file_find_first()).

blocks.html:
var _look_for_description = true;
var _file = file_find_first("/game_data/*.bin", fa_none);
file_find_close();
if (_look_for_description)
{
    _file2 = file_find_first("/game_data/*.json", fa_none);
    file_find_close();
}

diagnostics.title: Closing a File Find without opening a File Find.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you call file_find_close when no File Find is currently open (i.e. no call to file_find_first was made).
blocks.text: This message is shown when you call file_find_close when no File Find is currently open (i.e. no call to file_find_first was made).

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html: file_find_close();
blocks.text: file_find_close();

blocks.html: A call to file_find_first() should be added if the intention is to do a File Find.
blocks.text: A call to file_find_first() should be added if the intention is to do a File Find.

blocks.html:
file_find_first("*.json", fa_none);
file_find_close();
blocks.text:
file_find_first("*.json", fa_none);

    file_find_close();

diagnostics.title: The function '{0}' cannot be called outside of a file_find_first()/file_find_close() block.

blocks.html: This message indicates that the given function can only go between a call to file_find_first and a call to file_find_close.
blocks.text: This message indicates that the given function can only go between a call to file_find_first and a call to file_find_close.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
fnames = [];
var _fname = file_find_first("*.txt", fa_none);

while(_fname != "")
{
    array_push(fnames, _fname);
    _fname = file_find_next();
}

file_find_close();
file_find_next();
The second file_find_next() is called outside of the calls to file_find_first() and file_find_close(). It needs to be removed to fix the issue.
blocks.text: The second file_find_next() is called outside of the calls to file_find_first() and file_find_close(). It needs to be removed to fix the issue.

blocks.html:
fnames = [];
var _fname = file_find_first("*.txt", fa_none);

while(_fname != "")
{
    array_push(fnames, _fname);
    _fname = file_find_next();
}

file_find_close();

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call file_find_close() before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that a call to file_find_close may not be encountered. Ideally, the call to file_find_close() should occur in the same scope as the call to file_find_first().
blocks.text: This message indicates that a call to file_find_close may not be encountered. Ideally, the call to file_find_close() should occur in the same scope as the call to file_find_first().

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
fnames = [];
var _fname = file_find_first("*.txt", fa_none);
while(_fname != "")
{
    array_push(fnames, _fname);
    _fname = file_find_next();
}
In the code example, a call to file_find_close() is missing. This needs to be added to fix the issue.
blocks.text: In the code example, a call to file_find_close() is missing. This needs to be added to fix the issue.

blocks.html:
fnames = [];
var _fname = file_find_first("*.txt", fa_none);
while(_fname != "")
{
    array_push(fnames, _fname);
    _fname = file_find_next();
}
file_find_close();

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_pop_state() before end of script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that there are situations where gpu_pop_state isn't called, depending on your game's logic. This can occur when you have logic in your code where, for example, the if case contains a call to gpu_pop_state but the else case doesn't. Depending on whether the expression inside the if statement evaluates to true or false the function may not get called.
blocks.text: This message indicates that there are situations where gpu_pop_state isn't called, depending on your game's logic. This can occur when you have logic in your code where, for example, the if case contains a call to gpu_pop_state but the else case doesn't. Depending on whether the expression inside the if statement evaluates to true or false the function may not get called.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw End Event
gpu_push_state();
gpu_set_blendmode(bm_add);
if (show_name)
{
    draw_text(x, y, name);
    gpu_pop_state();
}
/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, $"Instances: {instance_count}");

In the code example, the GPU's current state is pushed onto the stack and the blend mode is then changed to bm_add. The GPU's state is then set back to the previous one, but only if an instance variable is true. This has consequences for the subsequent Draw GUI Event. The call to gpu_pop_state needs to be moved out of the if statement so it always executes.
blocks.text: In the code example, the GPU's current state is pushed onto the stack and the blend mode is then changed to bm_add. The GPU's state is then set back to the previous one, but only if an instance variable is true. This has consequences for the subsequent Draw GUI Event. The call to gpu_pop_state needs to be moved out of the if statement so it always executes.

blocks.html:
/// Draw End Event
gpu_push_state();
gpu_set_blendmode(bm_add);
if (show_name)
{
    draw_text(x, y, name);
}
gpu_pop_state();

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, $"Instances: {instance_count}");  // All good!

diagnostics.title: Call to execute a global script resource like a function is deprecated.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you call a script asset as a function. A script asset is not meant to be executed directly as a function. While the behaviour is still included in GameMaker, it is only there to support legacy code.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you call a script asset as a function. A script asset is not meant to be executed directly as a function. While the behaviour is still included in GameMaker, it is only there to support legacy code.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// my_function
show_debug_message("my_function calling!");  // Function call. Debug message is shown already!

/// Create Event
my_function();                               // Debug message is shown again!

If a script asset contains code that should be its own function, this code should be moved inside a new function definition inside the script. The new function gets the name of the script asset and the script asset can be renamed to a descriptive name that describes well what it contains (a group of functions, a collection of (global) variables, a collection of macros, etc.).
blocks.text: If a script asset contains code that should be its own function, this code should be moved inside a new function definition inside the script. The new function gets the name of the script asset and the script asset can be renamed to a descriptive name that describes well what it contains (a group of functions, a collection of (global) variables, a collection of macros, etc.).

blocks.html:
/// Functions (Script Asset)
function my_function()
{
    show_debug_message("my_function calling!");  // Function call as part of function definition. Nothing is shown (yet)!
}

/// Create Event
my_function();                                   // Actual function call, debug message is shown (only) at the intented time!

diagnostics.title: Call to event_inherited() in object with no parent event.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you call the function event_inherited in an object that either has no parent object or that has no ancestor in its parent-child hierarchy that defines the event.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you call the function event_inherited in an object that either has no parent object or that has no ancestor in its parent-child hierarchy that defines the event.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// obj_parent
// No Room Start event

/// obj_child.Room_Start
event_inherited();

In the code example, an object obj_child has an object obj_parent as its parent object. The parent object doesn't define a Room Start event yet the child object does and calls event_inherited(). The call to event_inherited() can be removed, or it can be commented out in case the event might get added later in the parent object.
blocks.text: In the code example, an object obj_child has an object obj_parent as its parent object. The parent object doesn't define a Room Start event yet the child object does and calls event_inherited(). The call to event_inherited() can be removed, or it can be commented out in case the event might get added later in the parent object.

blocks.html:
/// obj_parent
// No Room Start event

/// obj_child.Room_Start
event_inherited();

diagnostics.title: Inconsistent stack depth for gpu_push_state()/gpu_pop_state() blocks. All branches should call these functions an equal number of times.

blocks.html: This message indicates that gpu_push_state is called a different number of times than gpu_pop_state. Every call to gpu_push_state must be accompanied by a call to gpu_pop_state.
blocks.text: This message indicates that gpu_push_state is called a different number of times than gpu_pop_state. Every call to gpu_push_state must be accompanied by a call to gpu_pop_state.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
// Situation 1
gpu_push_state();
gpu_push_state();
// draw something
gpu_pop_state();

// Situation 2
gpu_push_state();
// draw_something
gpu_pop_state();
gpu_pop_state();

Every call to gpu_push_state in the code above must have a corresponding call to gpu_pop_state. Assuming that two stack pushes were meant in the first case and a single stack push in the second case, the code can be fixed as follows:
blocks.text: Every call to gpu_push_state in the code above must have a corresponding call to gpu_pop_state. Assuming that two stack pushes were meant in the first case and a single stack push in the second case, the code can be fixed as follows:

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
// Situation 1
gpu_push_state();
gpu_push_state();
// draw something
gpu_pop_state();
gpu_pop_state();

// Situation 2
gpu_push_state();
// draw_something
gpu_pop_state();

diagnostics.title: Attempting to access the local variable '{0}' outside of the scope it was defined in.

blocks.html: This warning is shown when you access a local variable either before it's defined or after it's gone out of scope.
blocks.text: This warning is shown when you access a local variable either before it's defined or after it's gone out of scope.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
// Attempt to access before it's defined
// Didn't come across variable definition yet
i = 0;
var i = 34;

// Attempting to access after the variable's gone out of scope
if (something_occurred)
{
    // Variable is defined inside curly braces,
    // remains "in scope" between these curly braces
    var _msg = "Something happened!";
}

// Variable went out of scope after the closing curly brace
_msg = "test";

You should make sure to always define local variables before accessing them. In case of the if statement the variable can simply be declared before the if so it stays in scope the entire time and can also be accessed from within the if statement.
blocks.text: You should make sure to always define local variables before accessing them. In case of the if statement the variable can simply be declared before the if so it stays in scope the entire time and can also be accessed from within the if statement.

blocks.html:
// Fix for access before it's defined
var i = 0;
i = 34;

// Fix for access after the variable's gone out of scope
var _msg;
if (something_occurred)
{
    // Variable can be accessed and modified from within if
    _msg = "Something happened!";
}

// Variable is still in scope now
_msg = "test";

diagnostics.title: Local variable '{0}' is already declared.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you declare a local variable with the same name as a local variable that already exists.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you declare a local variable with the same name as a local variable that already exists.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
// Situation 1: declared again
var i = 0;
var _num_elements = 20;
array = array_create(_num_elements);
repeat(_num_elements)
{
    array[i--] = irandom(100);
}
var i = 0;

// Situation 2: redeclared in a nested loop
for(var i = 0;i < 50;i++)
{
    for(var i = 0;i < 50;i++)
    {
        
    }
}

In the above example two situations are shown. In the first situation the local variable is declared and used in a repeat loop. After that, it is redeclared. In this case, it suffices to keep only the first declaration and change the other one to an assignment since the variable already exists at that point. In the second situation the same variable name is accidentally used for both loop counters in a nested for loop. This will cause the variable to increment not only in the outer loop but also in the inner loop. To fix this, the inner loop counter variable should be renamed.
blocks.text: In the above example two situations are shown. In the first situation the local variable is declared and used in a repeat loop. After that, it is redeclared. In this case, it suffices to keep only the first declaration and change the other one to an assignment since the variable already exists at that point. In the second situation the same variable name is accidentally used for both loop counters in a nested for loop. This will cause the variable to increment not only in the outer loop but also in the inner loop. To fix this, the inner loop counter variable should be renamed.

blocks.html:
// Situation 1: declared again
var i = 0;
var _num_elements = 20;
array = array_create(_num_elements);
repeat(_num_elements)
{
    array[i--] = irandom(100);
}
i = 0;

// Situation 2: redeclared in a nested loop
for(var i = 0;i < 50;i++)
{
    for(var j = 0;j < 50;j++)
    {
        
    }
}

diagnostics.title: Inconsistent stack depth for surface_set_target()/surface_reset_target() blocks. All branches should call these functions the same number of times.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've set the draw target to a surface more times than you've reset it back to the previous target. Every change to the draw target must be accompanied by a change back to the previous draw target. If you miss a call to surface_reset_target this may cause certain things to be drawn to a different surface.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've set the draw target to a surface more times than you've reset it back to the previous target. Every change to the draw target must be accompanied by a change back to the previous draw target. If you miss a call to surface_reset_target this may cause certain things to be drawn to a different surface.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
sf = -1;

/// Draw Event
if (!surface_exists(sf))
{
    sf = surface_create(128, 128);
}
surface_set_target(sf);
draw_clear_alpha(c_blue, 1);
draw_circle(50, 50, 20, false);
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, surface_get_texture(sf));

In the code example above, a surface is created and drawn to in the Draw event. The surface is set as the drawing target but the drawing target isn't reset properly. A vertex buffer is then submitted with the surface texture used as the texture. However, the drawing target is still set to the surface itself and the vertex buffer will be rendered to the surface.
blocks.text: In the code example above, a surface is created and drawn to in the Draw event. The surface is set as the drawing target but the drawing target isn't reset properly. A vertex buffer is then submitted with the surface texture used as the texture. However, the drawing target is still set to the surface itself and the vertex buffer will be rendered to the surface.

blocks.html: Adding a call to surface_reset_target() after drawing to the surface fixes the issue.
blocks.text: Adding a call to surface_reset_target() after drawing to the surface fixes the issue.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
sf = -1;

/// Draw Event
if (!surface_exists(sf))
{
    sf = surface_create(128, 128);
}
surface_set_target(sf);
draw_clear_alpha(c_blue, 1);
draw_circle(50, 50, 20, false);
surface_reset_target();
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, surface_get_texture(sf));

diagnostics.title: Unreachable code.

blocks.html: This message is shown when a part of your code cannot be reached in any way because the logic always prevents it from happening. For example, when the expression inside an if statement always evaluates to false, the code inside that if statement will never be executed.
blocks.text: This message is shown when a part of your code cannot be reached in any way because the logic always prevents it from happening. For example, when the expression inside an if statement always evaluates to false, the code inside that if statement will never be executed.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
if (false)
{
    // Unreachable code
}
To fix this you should change the expression so that there are cases where it can evaluate to true and the code inside the if case executes.
blocks.text: To fix this you should change the expression so that there are cases where it can evaluate to true and the code inside the if case executes.

blocks.html:
if (choose(true, false))
{
    // Code executed if 'true'
}

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_blendenable(true) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that gpu_set_blendenable(true) isn't called in all possible cases after you disable blending with gpu_set_blendenable(false). This can occur when you have logic in your code where, for example, the if case contains a call to gpu_set_blendenable(true) but the else case doesn't. Depending on whether the expression inside the if statement evaluates to true or false, the function may not get called and blending won't be enabled again for subsequent drawing.
blocks.text: This message indicates that gpu_set_blendenable(true) isn't called in all possible cases after you disable blending with gpu_set_blendenable(false). This can occur when you have logic in your code where, for example, the if case contains a call to gpu_set_blendenable(true) but the else case doesn't. Depending on whether the expression inside the if statement evaluates to true or false, the function may not get called and blending won't be enabled again for subsequent drawing.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_blendenable(false);
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, tex);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "Hello!");  // Text isn't drawn correctly
To fix this issue you need to re-enable alpha blending with another call to gpu_set_blendenable.
blocks.text: To fix this issue you need to re-enable alpha blending with another call to gpu_set_blendenable.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_blendenable(false);
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, tex);
gpu_set_blendenable(true);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "Hello!");  // Text is drawn correctly again

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_zfunc(cmpfunc_lessequal) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the function for z-testing but haven't set it back to the default cmpfunc_lessequal again. When depth testing is enabled with a call to gpu_set_ztestenable(true), by default a pixel that's written to the depth buffer is considered closer when its z value is less or equal (cmpfunc_lessequal) than the current depth value for that pixel.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the function for z-testing but haven't set it back to the default cmpfunc_lessequal again. When depth testing is enabled with a call to gpu_set_ztestenable(true), by default a pixel that's written to the depth buffer is considered closer when its z value is less or equal (cmpfunc_lessequal) than the current depth value for that pixel.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_ztestenable(true);
gpu_set_zfunc(cmpfunc_greater);
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, tex);
gpu_set_ztestenable(false);
The comparison function used for z-testing needs to be properly reset to cmpfunc_lessequal in another call to gpu_set_zfunc.
blocks.text: The comparison function used for z-testing needs to be properly reset to cmpfunc_lessequal in another call to gpu_set_zfunc.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_ztestenable(true);
gpu_set_zfunc(cmpfunc_greater);
vertex_submit(vb, pr_trianglelist, tex);
gpu_set_zfunc(cmpfunc_lessequal);
gpu_set_ztestenable(false);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_fog(false, c_black, 0, 1) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the GPU fog settings with a call to gpu_set_fog, but haven't reset them to the default fog settings afterwards. GPU fog is disabled by default.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the GPU fog settings with a call to gpu_set_fog, but haven't reset them to the default fog settings afterwards. GPU fog is disabled by default.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_fog(true, c_aqua, 0, 1000);
draw_self();
The fog needs to be disabled after drawing with fog enabled in order not to affect subsequent draw commands.
blocks.text: The fog needs to be disabled after drawing with fog enabled in order not to affect subsequent draw commands.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_fog(true, c_aqua, 0, 1000);
draw_self();
gpu_set_fog(false, c_black, 0, 1);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_cullmode(cull_noculling) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the cullmode using a call to gpu_set_cullmode, but haven't reset it to cull_noculling afterwards. When culling is enabled, the GPU will not draw the backside of triangles based on the winding order of the vertices, which is either clockwise or counter-clockwise.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the cullmode using a call to gpu_set_cullmode, but haven't reset it to cull_noculling afterwards. When culling is enabled, the GPU will not draw the backside of triangles based on the winding order of the vertices, which is either clockwise or counter-clockwise.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_cullmode(cull_clockwise);
shader_set(sh_lighting);
vertex_submit(vb_static_geometry, pr_trianglelist, -1);
shader_reset();

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "World 1");
In order to fix this issue the cullmode needs to be properly reset to cull_noculling or to the value that it had before.
blocks.text: In order to fix this issue the cullmode needs to be properly reset to cull_noculling or to the value that it had before.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_cullmode(cull_clockwise);
// OR
// var _cm = gpu_get_cullmode();
// gpu_set_cullmode(cull_clockwise);

shader_set(sh_lighting);
vertex_submit(vb_static_geometry, pr_trianglelist, -1);
shader_reset();

gpu_set_cullmode(cull_noculling);
// OR
// gpu_set_cullmode(_cm);

/// Draw GUI Event
draw_text(5, 5, "World 1");

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_colourwriteenable(true, true, true, true) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've disabled writing to at least one colour channel but haven't re-enabled writing to all colour channels afterwards.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've disabled writing to at least one colour channel but haven't re-enabled writing to all colour channels afterwards.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_colourwriteenable(true, true, true, false);
draw_sprite(sprite_index, 0, x, y);

In the code example above writing to the alpha channel is disabled for all draw calls that follow the call to gpu_set_colourwriteenable. No call to gpu_set_colourwriteenable() is made to reset this, however. Because of this, subsequent draw commands will also not write to the alpha channel. Another call to gpu_set_colourwriteenable() is needed to fix this, which restores writing to all colour channels.
blocks.text: In the code example above writing to the alpha channel is disabled for all draw calls that follow the call to gpu_set_colourwriteenable. No call to gpu_set_colourwriteenable() is made to reset this, however. Because of this, subsequent draw commands will also not write to the alpha channel. Another call to gpu_set_colourwriteenable() is needed to fix this, which restores writing to all colour channels.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_colourwriteenable(true, true, true, false);
draw_sprite(sprite_index, 0, x, y);
gpu_set_colourwriteenable(true, true, true, true);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_alphatestenable(false) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've enabled alpha testing but haven't disabled it again afterwards.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've enabled alpha testing but haven't disabled it again afterwards.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_alphatestenable(true);
draw_self();
To fix this you should disable alpha testing after drawing everything that needs to be drawn with alpha testing enabled.
blocks.text: To fix this you should disable alpha testing after drawing everything that needs to be drawn with alpha testing enabled.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_alphatestenable(true);
draw_self();
gpu_set_alphatestenable(false);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_alphatestref(0) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the alpha test ref value from the default value of 0 (using gpu_set_alphatestref) but haven't changed it back to 0 afterwards.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the alpha test ref value from the default value of 0 (using gpu_set_alphatestref) but haven't changed it back to 0 afterwards.

blocks.html: Note that the alpha test ref value is only used when alpha testing is enabled using gpu_set_alphatestenable.
blocks.text: Note that the alpha test ref value is only used when alpha testing is enabled using gpu_set_alphatestenable.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_alphatestenable(true);
gpu_set_alphatestref(127);
draw_sprite(sprite_index, 0, x, y);
The alpha test ref value should be reset back to 0 to prevent subsequent draw commands from being affected.
blocks.text: The alpha test ref value should be reset back to 0 to prevent subsequent draw commands from being affected.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
gpu_set_alphatestenable(true);
gpu_set_alphatestref(127);
draw_sprite(sprite_index, 0, x, y);
gpu_set_alphatestref(0);
gpu_set_alphatestenable(false);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_texfilter(false) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the texture filter setting to true but haven't changed it back to false afterwards. By default, texture filtering is set to disabled for all texture samplers.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the texture filter setting to true but haven't changed it back to false afterwards. By default, texture filtering is set to disabled for all texture samplers.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
tex = sprite_get_texture(spr_texpage, 0);

/// Draw Event
gpu_set_texfilter(true);
vertex_submit(vb_world, pr_trianglelist, tex);
After the call to gpu_set_texfilter and all draw commands that follow it you need to reset texture filtering to false, the default setting.
blocks.text: After the call to gpu_set_texfilter and all draw commands that follow it you need to reset texture filtering to false, the default setting.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
tex = sprite_get_texture(spr_texpage, 0);

/// Draw Event
gpu_set_texfilter(true);
vertex_submit(vb_world, pr_trianglelist, tex);
gpu_set_texfilter(false);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call gpu_set_texrepeat(false) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the texture repeat setting to true but haven't changed it back to false afterwards. By default, texture repeating is set to disabled for all texture samplers.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the texture repeat setting to true but haven't changed it back to false afterwards. By default, texture repeating is set to disabled for all texture samplers.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
tex = sprite_get_texture(spr_texpage, 0);

/// Draw Event
gpu_set_texrepeat(true);
vertex_submit(vb_world, pr_trianglelist, tex);
After the call to gpu_set_texrepeat and all draw commands that follow it you should reset the texture repeat to false, the default setting.
blocks.text: After the call to gpu_set_texrepeat and all draw commands that follow it you should reset the texture repeat to false, the default setting.

blocks.html:
