tex = sprite_get_texture(spr_texpage, 0);

/// Draw Event
gpu_set_texrepeat(true);
vertex_submit(vb_world, pr_trianglelist, tex);
gpu_set_texrepeat(false);

diagnostics.title: Opportunity to use nullish coalesce operator.

blocks.html: Shows when you are trying to check if an expression is undefined, and then applying a different value in that case:
blocks.text: Shows when you are trying to check if an expression is undefined, and then applying a different value in that case:

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
array = modify_array(array);
if (array == undefined) array = [];
blocks.text:
array = modify_array(array);

    if (array == undefined) array = [];

blocks.html: For this, the nullish operator can be used:
blocks.text: For this, the nullish operator can be used:

blocks.html: array = modify_array(array) ?? [];
blocks.text: array = modify_array(array) ?? [];

blocks.html: To keep a variable unchanged if the RHS expression is undefined, use this:
blocks.text: To keep a variable unchanged if the RHS expression is undefined, use this:

blocks.html: array ??= modify_array(array);
blocks.text: array ??= modify_array(array);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call draw_set_colour(c_white) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the draw colour to a colour that's different from c_white but haven't changed it back to c_white afterwards.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the draw colour to a colour that's different from c_white but haven't changed it back to c_white afterwards.

blocks.html: The draw colour is the colour that's used to blend the sprite with. A colour of c_white essentially multiplies all of the sprite's pixels' colours by 1, resulting in no change.
blocks.text: The draw colour is the colour that's used to blend the sprite with. A colour of c_white essentially multiplies all of the sprite's pixels' colours by 1, resulting in no change.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_set_colour(c_red);
draw_text(5, 5, "Hello!");
In the code example above, the draw colour used for drawing is set to c_red but isn't set back to c_white afterwards. This causes all subsequent draw commands to draw with that same draw colour.
blocks.text: In the code example above, the draw colour used for drawing is set to c_red but isn't set back to c_white afterwards. This causes all subsequent draw commands to draw with that same draw colour.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_set_colour(c_red);
draw_text(5, 5, "Hello!");
draw_set_colour(c_white);

diagnostics.title: Not all code paths call draw_set_alpha(1) before the end of the script.

blocks.html: This message indicates that you've changed the draw alpha to a value different from 1 using draw_set_alpha but haven't changed it back to 1.
blocks.text: This message indicates that you've changed the draw alpha to a value different from 1 using draw_set_alpha but haven't changed it back to 1.

blocks.html: The alpha value is the value that's used for blending each pixel of the sprite (the source) with the destination pixel.
blocks.text: The alpha value is the value that's used for blending each pixel of the sprite (the source) with the destination pixel.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_set_alpha(0.5);
draw_self();
In the code example above, the alpha value used for drawing is set to 0.5 but isn't set back to 1 afterwards. This causes all subsequent draw commands to draw with that same alpha value.
blocks.text: In the code example above, the alpha value used for drawing is set to 0.5 but isn't set back to 1 afterwards. This causes all subsequent draw commands to draw with that same alpha value.

blocks.html:
/// Draw Event
draw_set_alpha(0.5);
draw_self();
draw_set_alpha(1);

diagnostics.title: Variable '{0}' does not exist in object's Variable Definitions.

blocks.html: This message is shown when you create a new instance of an object using one of the instance_create_* functions and attempt to access variables that aren't defined in the object's Variable Definitions when assigning to the optional variable struct.
blocks.text: This message is shown when you create a new instance of an object using one of the instance_create_* functions and attempt to access variables that aren't defined in the object's Variable Definitions when assigning to the optional variable struct.

blocks.html: In the variable struct you can access variables from any scope, though in instance scope the only variables that exist at this point are the ones defined in the Variable Definitions.
blocks.text: In the variable struct you can access variables from any scope, though in instance scope the only variables that exist at this point are the ones defined in the Variable Definitions.

blocks.html: Important: object variables don't belong to the object but are initialised in every new instance created from that object. The first point in your code where you can access these variables is the var struct.
blocks.text: Important: object variables don't belong to the object but are initialised in every new instance created from that object. The first point in your code where you can access these variables is the var struct.

blocks.html: Example
blocks.text: Example

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
ins_companion = instance_create_layer(x, y, layer, obj_companion, {
    intro_message: message
});

// The message variable does not exist

Variables can only be accessed when they've first been defined. In the example above, the object doesn't have any variables defined but an attempt is made to access an instance variable named message. In order to fix this, the variable has to be defined in the object variables.
blocks.text: Variables can only be accessed when they've first been defined. In the example above, the object doesn't have any variables defined but an attempt is made to access an instance variable named message. In order to fix this, the variable has to be defined in the object variables.

blocks.html:
/// Create Event
ins_companion = instance_create_layer(x, y, layer, obj_companion, {
    intro_message: message
});
A Feather directive has the following syntax:
blocks.text: A Feather directive has the following syntax:

blocks.html: // Feather command parameters [in PATH]
blocks.text: // Feather command parameters [in PATH]

blocks.html: It is a regular script comment that starts with Feather, followed by the command and its parameters. Optionally, it may take a path to a script, object or group in The Asset Browser to which the directive is applied.
blocks.text: It is a regular script comment that starts with Feather, followed by the command and its parameters. Optionally, it may take a path to a script, object or group in The Asset Browser to which the directive is applied.

blocks.html: Specific feather rules can be ignored using the directive Feather ignore or Feather disable:
blocks.text: Specific feather rules can be ignored using the directive Feather ignore or Feather disable:

blocks.html:
// Feather ignore  GM1010
// Feather disable GM1010
blocks.text:
// Feather ignore  GM1010

    // Feather disable GM1010

blocks.html: For example, consider the following piece of code:
blocks.text: For example, consider the following piece of code:

blocks.html:
// Feather ignore GM1010
result = 5 + "5";
blocks.text:
// Feather ignore GM1010

    result = 5 + "5";

blocks.html: With Strict Type mode enabled, Feather normally shows a "GM1010 - Cannot perform '+' operation between types 'real' and 'string' message. With the directive above, Feather will ignore messages of this type, in that particular script.
blocks.text: With Strict Type mode enabled, Feather normally shows a "GM1010 - Cannot perform '+' operation between types 'real' and 'string' message. With the directive above, Feather will ignore messages of this type, in that particular script.

blocks.html: The directive only affects lines after the comment itself, so any statements before the comment will still show warnings.
blocks.text: The directive only affects lines after the comment itself, so any statements before the comment will still show warnings.

blocks.html: Ignoring Once
blocks.text: Ignoring Once

blocks.html: The GM message can be ignored only once by adding once:
blocks.text: The GM message can be ignored only once by adding once:

blocks.html: // Feather ignore once GM1010
blocks.text: // Feather ignore once GM1010

blocks.html: This command makes Feather ignore the first occurrence of this type of message but not the ones that come after that:
blocks.text: This command makes Feather ignore the first occurrence of this type of message but not the ones that come after that:

blocks.html:
// Feather ignore once GM1010
result = 5 + "5";    // ignored
result = 6 + "6";    // error
Restoring
blocks.text: Restoring

blocks.html: Finally, you can re-enable the GM message using restore / enable:
blocks.text: Finally, you can re-enable the GM message using restore / enable:

blocks.html:
// Feather restore GM1010
// Feather enable  GM1010
blocks.text:
// Feather restore GM1010

    // Feather enable  GM1010

blocks.html: This directive sets the profile for the script:
blocks.text: This directive sets the profile for the script:

blocks.html:
// Feather use syntax-errors
// Feather use type-errors
// Feather use all
// Feather use none
This Feather directive corresponds to the Profile preference in the Feather Preferences.
blocks.text: This Feather directive corresponds to the Profile preference in the Feather Preferences.

blocks.html: This directive sets the type validation mode to use from either strict or relaxed:
blocks.text: This directive sets the type validation mode to use from either strict or relaxed:

blocks.html:
/// Feather use strict
/// Feather use relaxed
blocks.text:
/// Feather use strict

    /// Feather use relaxed

blocks.html: This Feather directive corresponds to the Strict Type mode preference in the Feather Preferences.
blocks.text: This Feather directive corresponds to the Strict Type mode preference in the Feather Preferences.

blocks.html: You can also set the profile and type validation mode in a single line:
blocks.text: You can also set the profile and type validation mode in a single line:

blocks.html: /// Feather use all, strict
blocks.text: /// Feather use all, strict

blocks.html: The above comment will make Feather look for All errors and use Strict Type mode.
blocks.text: The above comment will make Feather look for All errors and use Strict Type mode.

blocks.html: Optionally you can provide a path using the in directive to apply a Feather directive to a specific script, object or group in The Asset Browser. This can be placed in the main script of an external library of functions, though you can place it in any other script, e.g. a blank "FeatherConfig" script.
blocks.text: Optionally you can provide a path using the in directive to apply a Feather directive to a specific script, object or group in The Asset Browser. This can be placed in the main script of an external library of functions, though you can place it in any other script, e.g. a blank "FeatherConfig" script.

blocks.html: Having numerous rules using paths may cause performance issues, the exception being paths set specifically to * alone.
blocks.text: Having numerous rules using paths may cause performance issues, the exception being paths set specifically to * alone.

blocks.html: You can use the following special symbols in your paths:
blocks.text: You can use the following special symbols in your paths:

blocks.html:
• / - When used in the beginning of a path, points to the root of the Asset Browser
  • . - When used in the beginning of a path, points to the current script's folder
  • * is a wildcard that matches everything inside the preceding directory
blocks.text:
/ - When used in the beginning of a path, points to the root of the Asset Browser
    . - When used in the beginning of a path, points to the current script's folder
    * is a wildcard that matches everything inside the preceding directory

blocks.html: This way you can define paths to assets in the Asset Browser, for example:
blocks.text: This way you can define paths to assets in the Asset Browser, for example:

blocks.html:
Path Applies To
/Scripts/* All assets in /Scripts
/* All assets
./* All assets in the current folder and subfolders
/Foo/Bar/obj_manager obj_manager in the /Foo/Bar folder
blocks.text: Path Applies To /Scripts/* All assets in /Scripts /* All assets ./* All assets in the current folder and subfolders /Foo/Bar/obj_manager obj_manager in the /Foo/Bar folder

blocks.html: Examples:
blocks.text: Examples:

blocks.html:
Directive Effect
// Feather ignore GM2017 in * Ignores all Naming Rule violations in the whole project
// Feather ignore GM1064 in ./* Ignores GM1064 in the current folder and all subfolders
// Feather use type-errors in /Objects/System/* Sets the profile to type-errors in specifically the Objects/System folder
// Feather use all in /Objects/System/obj_controller Sets the profile to all in obj_controller
blocks.text: Directive Effect // Feather ignore GM2017 in * Ignores all Naming Rule violations in the whole project // Feather ignore GM1064 in ./* Ignores GM1064 in the current folder and all subfolders // Feather use type-errors in /Objects/System/* Sets the profile to type-errors in specifically the Objects/System folder // Feather use all in /Objects/System/obj_controller Sets the profile to all in obj_controller

blocks.html: No consistent result is guaranteed if you have two directives that enable and disable a Feather message on the same path.
blocks.text: No consistent result is guaranteed if you have two directives that enable and disable a Feather message on the same path.

notes: This section allows you to set naming rules for assets, variables and various other parts of GML Code. Any newly created assets in the Asset Browser will follow the naming rules set here.
The GM2017 rule under "Message Severity" must be enabled for naming rules to take effect. By default, it's disabled (set to "Ignore").
The settings in this section are as follows:
namingRules.identifierBlocklist:
Identifier Blocklist: This is a space-separated list of identifiers that will be ignored for all naming rules.



      For example, say you have a rule to use obj_ as a prefix for objects, but you want your objects manager and network to remain as-is and not use the obj_ prefix.



      In that case, you would write manager network into the Identifier Blocklist field. Feather will ignore those objects and any other identifiers (variables, enums, parameters, etc.) with the same names.
namingRules.identifierRuleSummary:
<identifier> Naming Rule: You can set naming rules for each type of identifier in the list, such as assets, macros, enums, function parameters, variables, etc.



      Each naming rule drop-down has the following options:

        Naming Style: Choose the naming style for the identifier. Your options are:

            Unconstrained: No formatting is forced on this type of identifier.
            UpperCamelCase: MyHealth, ObjGrappleHook
            lowerCamelCase: myHealth, objGrappleHook
            ALL_UPPER: MY_HEALTH, OBJ_GRAPPLE_HOOK
            all_lower: my_health, obj_grapple_hook


        Prefix: Text that should appear before the identifier name, which may be obj_ for objects, _ for local variables, etc. depending on your preferences.
        Suffix: Text that should appear after the identifier name.
        Preserve trailing and leading underscores: If enabled, preserves underscores around your asset's name even after suggestions.



          With this, you can use asset names such as __objCamera, keeping any leading and trailing underscores where they are.
namingStyleOptions: Unconstrained: No formatting is forced on this type of identifier.

introBlocks.html: Feather uses data types to provide smart syntax-checking when writing code, ensuring you don't use the wrong data type for a variable or function parameter.
introBlocks.text: Feather uses data types to provide smart syntax-checking when writing code, ensuring you don't use the wrong data type for a variable or function parameter.

introBlocks.html: It also allows you to specify the data types for the parameters and return values of your own script functions, using JSDoc comments.
introBlocks.text: It also allows you to specify the data types for the parameters and return values of your own script functions, using JSDoc comments.

introBlocks.html: The @param and @return JSDoc tags allow you specify any one of the following types:
introBlocks.text: The @param and @return JSDoc tags allow you specify any one of the following types:

introBlocks.html: NOTE JSDoc base types are case-insensitive, so string and String are the same, however specifiers (after the .) are case-sensitive, meaning Id.DsList is valid (referring to a DS List) but Id.dslist is not.
introBlocks.text: NOTE JSDoc base types are case-insensitive, so string and String are the same, however specifiers (after the .) are case-sensitive, meaning Id.DsList is valid (referring to a DS List) but Id.dslist is not.

baseTypes.name: Struct
baseTypes.description: A struct, may include specifiers (such as constructors)

baseTypes.name: Id
baseTypes.specifierHtml:
.Instance - Object Instance
.DsList - DS List
.DsMap - DS Map
.DsGrid - DS Grid
.DsStack - DS Stack

...

...

noteBlocks.html: NOTE JSDoc base types are case-insensitive, so string and String are the same, however specifiers (after the .) are case-sensitive, meaning Id.DsList is valid (referring to a DS List) but Id.dslist is not.
noteBlocks.text: NOTE JSDoc base types are case-insensitive, so string and String are the same, however specifiers (after the .) are case-sensitive, meaning Id.DsList is valid (referring to a DS List) but Id.dslist is not.

noteBlocks.html: NOTE * The Specifier Examples column lists some example specifiers, but not all of them. For example, there may be more possible types under the Id, Asset, and Constant groups, which are not listed here.
noteBlocks.text: NOTE * The Specifier Examples column lists some example specifiers, but not all of them. For example, there may be more possible types under the Id, Asset, and Constant groups, which are not listed here.

blocks.html: A specifier is added after the base data type using a dot ., to specify the exact type of data in that group.
blocks.text: A specifier is added after the base data type using a dot ., to specify the exact type of data in that group.

blocks.html: Types such as Id.DsList, Asset.GMObject, and Constant.Color use specifiers. Constructors are specified through the syntax Struct.{ConstructorName}. For example:
blocks.text: Types such as Id.DsList, Asset.GMObject, and Constant.Color use specifiers. Constructors are specified through the syntax Struct.{ConstructorName}. For example:

blocks.html:
function Person() constructor
{

}

/// @param {Struct.Person} _person
function do_business(_person)
{

}
Types such as Array and Id.DsList, which are data structures that contain multiple values, are able to specify a single data type for all of their contents.
blocks.text: Types such as Array and Id.DsList, which are data structures that contain multiple values, are able to specify a single data type for all of their contents.

blocks.html: This is done using Collection Types, which are appended to the type using angle brackets <>.
blocks.text: This is done using Collection Types, which are appended to the type using angle brackets <>.

blocks.html: For example, an array containing strings would be Array<String>, and a DS List, containing an Array, containing Reals, would be Id.DsList<Array<Real>>.
blocks.text: For example, an array containing strings would be Array<String>, and a DS List, containing an Array, containing Reals, would be Id.DsList<Array<Real>>.

blocks.html: Multiple data types can also be listed, separated by a comma ,. For example String,Array<String>, Id.Instance,Asset.GMObject, etc.
